However, the mediation failed, as President Lee could not persuade James Soong to withdraw. Soong publicly claimed that his candidacy was to \"save the country and the people,\" not for personal grudges. This publicly failed mediation did not resolve the crisis; instead, it proved to the entire electorate that the KMT, this century-old party that had ruled for fifty years, could not even control its own sitting chairman, and the system began to show cracks." } }, { "model": "campaign_trail.answer_feedback", "pk": 19991732, "fields": { "answer": 19991729, "candidate": 68, "answer_feedback": "Our strategy successfully stabilized the deep-Blue and Huang Fu Hsing base, limiting Soong's Mainland-descent vote source to swing voters. However, his influence among mainlanders remains strong. Although you are the KMT's orthodox candidate, James Soong will always be their second choice." } }, { "model": "campaign_trail.answer_feedback", "pk": 19991734, "fields": { "answer": 19991730, "candidate": 68, "answer_feedback": "Our localization campaign alienated many deep-Blue supporters who disliked Lee Teng-hui, accelerating their shift to Soong. At the same time, we were at a disadvantage against Chen Shui-bian in the South, as voters believed that the \"true localist is Chen Shui-bian,\" and we were merely \"pretending to be local\" for votes. The result is that we failed to fully capture votes on either side: deep-Blue votes went to Soong, and localist votes went to Chen, leaving us caught in the middle and in a difficult position." } }, { "model": "campaign_trail.answer_feedback", "pk": 19991738, "fields": { "answer": 19991731, "candidate": 68, "answer_feedback": "Although our rational campaign won the support of some intellectuals and business voters, our image appeared overly \"aloof\" and \"aristocratic.\" At the grassroots level, facing Soong's powerful local factions and Chen Shui-bian's passionate popular appeal, we lacked sufficient mobilization and infectiousness. function onGameWindowChanged(mutationList, observer) { updateQuestionBanner(); createAllCandidateBoxes( currentCandName, // 使用全局变量 currentCandTitle, // 使用全局变量 currentMateName, // 使用全局变量 currentMateTitle // 使用全局变量 ); updateadvisor(); // === 加入到这里 === addDataCenterButton(); // ================== } function updateadvisor() { if(e.lien == 1) { 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/686c24e6-ca71-41d9-9311-75e7ac19ce15.jpg?v=1765540894473', 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/176561160688816_P8459104.jpg?v=1765611658892', 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/d5ba95f2aec08340e68bd0527846651d.jpg?v=1765622884227', 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/1999.12.050.01.cut.webp?v=1765624316638', 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/jpg_00_01_08_80_cca220002-hp-200003250766000000l-0001-i.jpg?v=1765631732427', 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/2c012be8-1a34-44ae-a3b9-240f3415eadf.jpg?v=1765639178368', 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/d3622507.jpg?v=1764755730256', 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/710d6326787fdee43d85f4c78a7770fd.jpg?v=1765643453549', 'https://i.imgur.com/Xgzqlmo.jpeg' // ... 請確保這裡有 26 個 URL (索引 0 到 25) ]; function updateQuestionBanner() { // 1. 獲取當前問題的索引 (直接就是 0, 1, 2...) const currentQIndex = campaignTrail_temp.question_number; const picWidth = 160; const picHeight = 203; // 2. 查找 DOM 元素 let questionBanner = document.getElementById("campaign_sign"); document.getElementById("header").src = "https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/liensiew.png?v=1765108257853"; // 檢查舊元素 if (!questionBanner || questionBanner.nodeName != "DIV") return; // 3. 創建圖片元素 let img = document.createElement('img'); let imageSource = null; // 4. 核心 MOD 判斷邏輯：確保索引有效 if (currentQIndex >= 0 && currentQIndex < MOD_IMAGE_URLS.length) { // ** 直接使用索引從 Mod 陣列中取圖 ** imageSource = MOD_IMAGE_URLS[currentQIndex]; // 額外：如果您想設定背景，可以在這裡執行 $("#game_window")[0].style.backgroundColor = 'rgb(19, 66, 120)'; } else { // 索引無效時的後備圖片 imageSource = 'https://i.imgur.com/Default_Fallback_Image.png'; console.warn(`Mod 警告: 索引 ${currentQIndex} 無效，使用後備圖片。`); } // 5. 設定圖片 src img.src = imageSource; // 6. 替換舊元素 questionBanner.replaceWith(img); } /** * 遍历并替换 candidate_pic 和 running_mate_pic 元素， * 将它们包裹在带有指定样式和文本的容器中。 */ /** * 遍历并替换 candidate_pic 和 running_mate_pic 元素， * 将它们包裹在带有指定样式和文本的容器中。 * * @param {string} candName - 候选人姓名 * @param {string} candTitle - 候选人职务/头衔 * @param {string} mateName - 副手或政党名称 * @param {string} mateTitle - 副手职务或政党头衔 */ function createAllCandidateBoxes(candName, candTitle, mateName, mateTitle) { // 设置固定的尺寸 const picWidth = 160; const picHeight = 203; // ========================================================= // 1. 候选人 (candidate_pic) 信息框创建逻辑 (左浮动) // ========================================================= // ⭐ 直接使用传入的参数 candName 和 candTitle const originalPic = document.getElementById('candidate_pic'); if (originalPic && !document.getElementById('candidate_box_wrapper')) { const wrapper = document.createElement('div'); wrapper.id = 'candidate_box_wrapper'; wrapper.style.cssText = ` border: 2px solid white; padding: 5px; text-align: center; display: inline-block; background-color: #e5e5e5; color: black; float: left; margin-right: 15px; margin-left: 10em; max-width: ${picWidth + 10}px; `; const pic = originalPic.cloneNode(true); pic.id = ''; pic.style.width = `${picWidth}px`; pic.style.height = `${picHeight}px`; pic.style.objectFit = 'cover'; const nameDiv = document.createElement('div'); nameDiv.textContent = candName; // ⭐ 使用参数 nameDiv.style.cssText = 'color: black; font-weight: bold; margin-top: 5px;'; const titleDiv = document.createElement('div'); titleDiv.textContent = candTitle; // ⭐ 使用参数 titleDiv.style.cssText = 'color: black; font-size: 0.9em;'; wrapper.appendChild(pic); wrapper.appendChild(nameDiv); wrapper.appendChild(titleDiv); const parent = originalPic.parentNode; parent.replaceChild(wrapper, originalPic); } // ========================================================= // 2. 副手/政党 (running_mate_pic) 信息框创建逻辑 (右浮动) // ========================================================= // ⭐ 直接使用传入的参数 mateName 和 mateTitle const originalMatePic = document.getElementById('running_mate_pic'); if (originalMatePic && !document.getElementById('running_mate_box_wrapper')) { const mateWrapper = document.createElement('div'); mateWrapper.id = 'running_mate_box_wrapper'; mateWrapper.style.cssText = ` border: 2px solid white; padding: 5px; text-align: center; display: inline-block; background-color: #e5e5e5; color: black; float: right; margin-left: 15px; margin-right: 10em; max-width: ${picWidth + 10}px; `; const matePic = originalMatePic.cloneNode(true); matePic.id = ''; matePic.style.width = `${picWidth}px`; matePic.style.height = `${picHeight}px`; matePic.style.objectFit = 'cover'; const mateNameDiv = document.createElement('div'); mateNameDiv.textContent = mateName; // ⭐ 使用参数 mateNameDiv.style.cssText = 'color: black; font-weight: bold; margin-top: 5px;'; const mateTitleDiv = document.createElement('div'); mateTitleDiv.textContent = mateTitle; // ⭐ 使用参数 mateTitleDiv.style.cssText = 'color: black; font-size: 0.9em;'; mateWrapper.appendChild(matePic); mateWrapper.appendChild(mateNameDiv); mateWrapper.appendChild(mateTitleDiv); const mateParent = originalMatePic.parentNode; mateParent.replaceChild(mateWrapper, originalMatePic); } } e.cyoa = true e = campaignTrail_temp //开始变量 //面对的候选人 e.lien = 1; if (typeof campaignTrail_temp.LienShiftApplied === 'undefined') { campaignTrail_temp.LienShiftApplied = false; } function LienIssueShift_PartyCoalition_minus() { // 檢查標誌，如果已經執行過，則立即退出，防止分數累積。 if (campaignTrail_temp.LienShiftApplied) { console.warn("LienIssueShift_FixedDelta_Safe 已經執行過，跳過調整。"); return; } console.log("正在執行連戰議題的固定幅度 (-0.05) 調整..."); // 🌟 關鍵修正：定義所有政策的固定 Delta 為 -0.05 (或 0.05) 🌟 const adjustments = [ // PK 328: 原始 0.5。調整 -0.05，最終 0.45 { pk: 333, delta: -0.05, name: "Party Coalition" }, ]; const issueArray = campaignTrail_temp.candidate_issue_score_json; adjustments.forEach(adj => { const id = issueArray.findIndex(p => p.pk === adj.pk); if (id !== -1) { const issueFields = issueArray[id].fields; const currentScore = issueFields.issue_score; // 核心邏輯：將當前分數加上固定的 Delta (-0.05) issueFields.issue_score += adj.delta; console.log(`PK ${adj.pk} (${adj.name}): 從 ${currentScore.toFixed(3)} 調整了 ${adj.delta.toFixed(3)} 變為 ${issueFields.issue_score.toFixed(3)}`); } }); // 設置標誌，表示已完成調整 campaignTrail_temp.LienShiftApplied = true; } // 狀態標誌的初始化： if (typeof campaignTrail_temp.LienShift_PK329_Applied === 'undefined') { campaignTrail_temp.LienShift_PK329_Applied = false; } function LienIssueShift_Provincial_minus() { // 檢查標誌，如果已經執行過，則立即退出，防止分數累積。 if (campaignTrail_temp.LienShift_PK329_Applied) { console.warn("LienIssueShift_Provincial_minus 已經執行過，跳過調整。"); return; } console.log("正在執行 PK 334 (Provincial) 的固定幅度 (-0.05) 調整..."); const adjustments = [ // PK 334: 調整 -0.05 { pk: 334, delta: -0.05, name: "Provincial: Mostly Mainlanders" }, ]; const issueArray = campaignTrail_temp.candidate_issue_score_json; adjustments.forEach(adj => { const id = issueArray.findIndex(p => p.pk === adj.pk); if (id !== -1) { const issueFields = issueArray[id].fields; const currentScore = issueFields.issue_score; issueFields.issue_score += adj.delta; console.log(`PK ${adj.pk} (${adj.name}): 從 ${currentScore.toFixed(3)} 調整了 ${adj.delta.toFixed(3)} 變為 ${issueFields.issue_score.toFixed(3)}`); } }); // 設置獨立標誌 campaignTrail_temp.LienShift_PK329_Applied = true; } // 狀態標誌的初始化： if (typeof campaignTrail_temp.LienShift_PK330_Applied === 'undefined') { campaignTrail_temp.LienShift_PK330_Applied = false; } function LienIssueShift_LocalLegislators_minus() { // 檢查標誌，如果已經執行過，則立即退出，防止分數累積。 if (campaignTrail_temp.LienShift_PK330_Applied) { console.warn("LienIssueShift_LocalLegislators_minus 已經執行過，跳過調整。"); return; } console.log("正在執行 PK 335 (政治改革) 的固定幅度 (-0.05) 調整..."); const adjustments = [ // PK 335: 調整 -0.05 { pk: 335, delta: -0.05, name: "政治改革: 政治改革" }, ]; const issueArray = campaignTrail_temp.candidate_issue_score_json; adjustments.forEach(adj => { const id = issueArray.findIndex(p => p.pk === adj.pk); if (id !== -1) { const issueFields = issueArray[id].fields; const currentScore = issueFields.issue_score; issueFields.issue_score += adj.delta; console.log(`PK ${adj.pk} (${adj.name}): 從 ${currentScore.toFixed(3)} 調整了 ${adj.delta.toFixed(3)} 變為 ${issueFields.issue_score.toFixed(3)}`); } }); // 設置獨立標誌 campaignTrail_temp.LienShift_PK330_Applied = true; } // 狀態標誌的初始化： if (typeof campaignTrail_temp.LienShift_PK331_Applied === 'undefined') { campaignTrail_temp.LienShift_PK331_Applied = false; } function LienIssueShift_NationalIdentity_minus() { // 檢查標誌，如果已經執行過，則立即退出，防止分數累積。 if (campaignTrail_temp.LienShift_PK331_Applied) { console.warn("LienIssueShift_NationalIdentity_minus 已經執行過，跳過調整。"); return; } console.log("正在執行 PK 336 (National identity) 的固定幅度 (-0.05) 調整..."); const adjustments = [ // PK 336: 調整 -0.05 { pk: 336, delta: -0.05, name: "National identity" }, ]; const issueArray = campaignTrail_temp.candidate_issue_score_json; adjustments.forEach(adj => { const id = issueArray.findIndex(p => p.pk === adj.pk); if (id !== -1) { const issueFields = issueArray[id].fields; const currentScore = issueFields.issue_score; issueFields.issue_score += adj.delta; console.log(`PK ${adj.pk} (${adj.name}): 從 ${currentScore.toFixed(3)} 調整了 ${adj.delta.toFixed(3)} 變為 ${issueFields.issue_score.toFixed(3)}`); } }); // 設置獨立標誌 campaignTrail_temp.LienShift_PK331_Applied = true; } // 狀態標誌的初始化： if (typeof campaignTrail_temp.LienShift_PK332_Applied === 'undefined') { campaignTrail_temp.LienShift_PK332_Applied = false; } function LienIssueShift_AttitudeTowardsLee_minus() { // 檢查標誌，如果已經執行過，則立即退出，防止分數累積。 if (campaignTrail_temp.LienShift_PK332_Applied) { console.warn("LienIssueShift_AttitudeTowardsLee_minus 已經執行過，跳過調整。"); return; } console.log("正在執行 PK 337 (Attitude towards Lee) 的固定幅度 (-0.05) 調整..."); const adjustments = [ // PK 337: 調整 -0.05 { pk: 337, delta: -0.05, name: "Attitude towards Lee Teng-hui" }, ]; const issueArray = campaignTrail_temp.candidate_issue_score_json; adjustments.forEach(adj => { const id = issueArray.findIndex(p => p.pk === adj.pk); if (id !== -1) { const issueFields = issueArray[id].fields; const currentScore = issueFields.issue_score; issueFields.issue_score += adj.delta; console.log(`PK ${adj.pk} (${adj.name}): 從 ${currentScore.toFixed(3)} 調整了 ${adj.delta.toFixed(3)} 變為 ${issueFields.issue_score.toFixed(3)}`); } }); // 設置獨立標誌 campaignTrail_temp.LienShift_PK332_Applied = true; } // 清除標誌，允許下次調用時再次調整分數 function ResetLienShiftStatus_PartyCoalition() { campaignTrail_temp.LienShiftApplied = false; } function ResetLienShiftStatus_Provincial() { campaignTrail_temp.LienShift_PK329_Applied = false; } function ResetLienShiftStatus_LocalLegislators() { campaignTrail_temp.LienShift_PK330_Applied = false; } function ResetLienShiftStatus_NationalIdentity() { campaignTrail_temp.LienShift_PK331_Applied = false; } this.stateShapes[s]; this.stateHitAreas[s] = n.path(r[s]).attr({ fill: "#000", "stroke-width": 0, opacity: 0, cursor: "pointer" }); this.stateHitAreas[s].node.dataState = s } this._onClickProxy = e.proxy(this, "_onClick"); this._onMouseOverProxy = e.proxy(this, "_onMouseOver"), this._onMouseOutProxy = e.proxy(this, "_onMouseOut"); for (var s in this.stateHitAreas) { this.stateHitAreas[s].toFront(); e(this.stateHitAreas[s].node).bind("mouseout", this._onMouseOutProxy); e(this.stateHitAreas[s].node).bind("click", this._onClickProxy); e(this.stateHitAreas[s].node).bind("mouseover", this._onMouseOverProxy) } }, _initCreateLabels: function() { var t = this.paper; var n = []; var r = 860; var i = 220; var s = this.options.labelWidth; var o = this.options.labelHeight; var u = this.options.labelGap; var a = this.options.labelRadius; var f = s / this.scale; var l = o / this.scale; var c = (s + u) / this.scale; var h = (o + u) / this.scale * .5; var p = a / this.scale; var d = this.options.labelBackingStyles; var v = this.options.labelTextStyles; var m = {}; for (var g = 0, y, b, w; g < n.length; ++g) { w = n[g]; y = (g + 1) % 2 * c + r; b = g * h + i; m = {}; if (this.options.stateSpecificLabelBackingStyles[w]) { e.extend(m, d, this.options.stateSpecificLabelBackingStyles[w]) } else { m = d } this.labelShapes[w] = t.rect(y, b, f, l, p).attr(m); m = {}; if (this.options.stateSpecificLabelTextStyles[w]) { e.extend(m, v, this.options.stateSpecificLabelTextStyles[w]) } else { e.extend(m, v) } if (m["font-size"]) { m["font-size"] = parseInt(m["font-size"]) / this.scale + "px" } this.labelTexts[w] = t.text(y + f / 2, b + l / 2, w).attr(m); this.labelHitAreas[w] = t.rect(y, b, f, l, p).attr({ fill: "#000", "stroke-width": 0, opacity: 0, cursor: "pointer" }); this.labelHitAreas[w].node.dataState = w } for (var w in this.labelHitAreas) { this.labelHitAreas[w].toFront(); e(this.labelHitAreas[w].node).bind("mouseout", this._onMouseOutProxy); e(this.labelHitAreas[w].node).bind("click", this._onClickProxy); e(this.labelHitAreas[w].node).bind("mouseover", this._onMouseOverProxy) } }, _getStateFromEvent: function(e) { var t = e.target && e.target.dataState || e.dataState; return this._getState(t) }, _getState: function(e) { var t = this.stateShapes[e]; var n = this.stateHitAreas[e]; var r = this.labelShapes[e]; var i = this.labelTexts[e]; var s = this.labelHitAreas[e]; return { shape: t, hitArea: n, name: e, labelBacking: r, labelText: i, labelHitArea: s } }, _onMouseOut: function(e) { var t = this._getStateFromEvent(e); if (!t.hitArea) { return } return !this._triggerEvent("mouseout", e, t) }, _defaultMouseOutAction: function(t) { var n = {}; if (this.options.stateSpecificStyles[t.name]) { e.extend(n, this.options.stateStyles, this.options.stateSpecificStyles[t.name]) } else { n = this.options.stateStyles } t.shape.animate(n, this.options.stateHoverAnimation); if (t.labelBacking) { var n = {}; if (this.options.stateSpecificLabelBackingStyles[t.name]) { e.extend(n, this.options.labelBackingStyles, this.options.stateSpecificLabelBackingStyles[t.name]) } else { n = this.options.labelBackingStyles } t.labelBacking.animate(n, this.options.stateHoverAnimation) } }, _onClick: function(e) { var t = this._getStateFromEvent(e); if (!t.hitArea) { return } return !this._triggerEvent("click", e, t) }, _onMouseOver: function(e) { var t = this._getStateFromEvent(e); if (!t.hitArea) { return } return !this._triggerEvent("mouseover", e, t) }, _defaultMouseOverAction: function(t) { this.bringShapeToFront(t.shape); this.paper.safari(); var n = {}; if (this.options.stateSpecificHoverStyles[t.name]) { e.extend(n, this.options.stateHoverStyles, this.options.stateSpecificHoverStyles[t.name]) } else { n = this.options.stateHoverStyles } t.shape.animate(n, this.options.stateHoverAnimation); if (t.labelBacking) { var n = {}; if (this.options.stateSpecificLabelBackingHoverStyles[t.name]) { e.extend(n, this.options.labelBackingHoverStyles, this.options.stateSpecificLabelBackingHoverStyles[t.name]) } else { n = this.options.labelBackingHoverStyles } t.labelBacking.animate(n, this.options.stateHoverAnimation) } }, _triggerEvent: function(t, n, r) { var i = r.name; var s = false; var o = e.Event("usmap" + t + i); o.originalEvent = n; if (this.options[t + "State"][i]) { s = this.options[t + "State"][i](o, r) === false } if (o.isPropagationStopped()) { this.element.trigger(o, [r]); s = s || o.isDefaultPrevented() } if (!o.isPropagationStopped()) { var u = e.Event("usmap" + t); u.originalEvent = n; if (this.options[t]) { s = this.options[t](u, r) === false || s } if (!u.isPropagationStopped()) { this.element.trigger(u, [r]); s = s || u.isDefaultPrevented() } } if (!s) { switch (t) { case "mouseover": this._defaultMouseOverAction(r); break; case "mouseout": this._defaultMouseOutAction(r); break } } return !s }, trigger: function(e, t, n) { t = t.replace("usmap", ""); e = e.toUpperCase(); var r = this._getState(e); this._triggerEvent(t, n, r) }, bringShapeToFront: function(e) { if (this.topShape) { e.insertAfter(this.topShape) } this.topShape = e } }; var c = []; s(e, "usmap", l, c) })(jQuery, document, window, Raphael) // constructs endings based on header and pages construct = (a = 1) => { e.page = e.page + a < e.pages.length ? e.page + a : 0 let html = e.header; html += e.pages[e.page] + "
"; html += `
`; if (e.page > 0) { html += ``; } if (e.page < e.pages.length - 1) { html += ``; } for (i in e.executable) { if (e.executable[i][0] == e.page) { e.executable[i][1](); } } if (e.image == true) setTimeout(()=>{ candImg = $(".person_image")[0] if (candImg) { candImg.remove() $("#final_results_description")[0].style = ` display: block; margin-left: auto; ` } }, 10) else if (e.image) setTimeout(()=>{ candImg = $(".person_image")[0]; if (candImg) { candImg.src = e.image; $("#final_results_description")[0].style = ` display: block; margin-left: auto; ` } }, 10) const resultsDescriptionElement = document.getElementById('results_container'); if (resultsDescriptionElement) { resultsDescriptionElement.scrollTop = 0; } return html; } endingConstructor = (a = 1) => { $("#final_results_description")[0].innerHTML = construct(a); } // ENDINGS -- this is slightly more reliable than the ending code method e.header = "

"]; e.page = 0; var songChange = 0; if (!document.getElementById("ending-slide-style")) { const style = document.createElement("style"); style.id = "ending-slide-style"; style.innerHTML = ` @keyframes tvFadeIn { 0% { opacity: 0; style.id = "ending-slide-style"; style.innerHTML = ` @keyframes tvFadeIn { 0% { opacity: 0; clip-path: inset(0% 0 100% 0); /* Fully clipped from top down */ filter: brightness(2); } 10% { clip-path: inset(0% 0 90% 0); The Twilight of the Immortals

March 18, 2000 — KMT Campaign Headquarters, Taipei

I. The Hubris of the Afternoon (14:00)

The day began with the scent of orchids and the unshakable arrogance of a party that has owned this island for half a century. At 2:00 PM, the Kuomintang headquarters on Ren'ai Road was not a war room; it was a coronation hall waiting for its king. The air conditioning hummed with a sterile, expensive silence, chilling the sweat on the necks of the junior staffers who scurried across the marble floors.

Men in sharp, dark suits—the old guard, the technocrats, the beneficiaries of the "Taiwan Miracle"—stood in clusters, sipping lukewarm tea from porcelain cups. They spoke in hushed, confident tones about the "Iron Vote," the "Stability Card," and the mobilization of the military dependents' villages. They laughed about Chen Shui-bian, dismissing him as a street agitator, a noisy disruption that the silent majority would surely silence. They sneered at James Soong, the traitor, the prodigal son who dared to challenge the machinery of the state.

Lien Chan was upstairs, insulated from the grime of the electorate. He was the chosen one, the man born with a silver spoon, the scholar-prince whom Lee Teng-hui had anointed. The mood was not just optimistic; it was inevitable. The spreadsheets on the desks predicted a comfortable margin. "The people crave stability," a senior advisor said, checking his Rolex. "They will not gamble their future on a lawyer."

II. The First Tremors (16:30)

The first crack in the marble facade appeared shortly after the polls closed. It wasn't a noise, but a silence that spread contagiously from the data entry room to the main hall. The television screens, stacked like a wall of judgment, began to flash the initial numbers from the south. Kaohsiung. Tainan. Pingtung.

Green. An ocean of Green.

"It's just the rural areas," someone shouted, their voice cracking slightly. "Wait for Taipei. Wait for the North."

But then came the numbers from Taichung, and the room grew colder. It wasn't just that Chen was leading; it was that James Soong was devouring the KMT's heart from the inside out. Every vote for Soong was a knife in Lien's back, a vote stolen from the "Blue" family. The faces of the campaign managers turned ashen. The confident chatter died, replaced by the frenetic clicking of calculators and the ringing of phones that went unanswered.

Jason Hu walked through the room, his usual diplomatic charm straining under the weight of reality. He looked at the whiteboard, where the gap was not closing—it was widening. He saw the panic in the eyes of the volunteers, young men and women who had believed in the invincibility of the party, now witnessing the impossible. The "Golden Decade" was dissolving into pixels on a screen.

III. The Exodus (18:00)

By 6:00 PM, the denial had mutated into horror. The grand hall, once teeming with dignitaries hoping to be seen near the future President, began to empty. It was a subtle, shameful exodus. High-ranking party officials, business tycoons, and local faction leaders—men who had sworn eternal loyalty only hours ago—began to check their watches and slip out the back exits.

They drifted away like smoke. No one wanted to be photographed in the epicenter of a catastrophe. The VIP section, laid out with champagne and flowers, looked like a wedding reception where the groom had died at the altar.

Inside the private holding room, Lien Chan sat motionless. He looked like a man trying to solve a complex equation in a language he did not speak. How could this happen? He had the endorsement of the Nobel laureates. He had the organization. He had the money.

Beside him, Lien Fang-yu maintained a terrifying composure. Her makeup was flawless, her dress impeccable, but her eyes betrayed a deep, bewildered hurt. They were the Royal Family of the Republic of China, and the subjects were revolting. They were being rejected not for a policy, but for their very existence. The realization was a slow, agonizing poison.

IV. The Rage of the Betrayed (19:15)

The atmosphere shifted from depression to terror as the sound from the street began to penetrate the thick glass of the headquarters. It wasn't the celebratory roar of the DPP; that was happening elsewhere. This was a low, guttural growl, the sound of a wounded beast.

Thousands of KMT supporters, waving blue flags now tattered by the rain, were gathering outside. But they were not chanting for Lien. They were screaming for blood.

"Lee Teng-hui, Step Down!"
"Traitor! Judas!"
"He sold us out! He gave it to Chen!"

The conspiracy theory spread like wildfire through the crowd: President Lee Teng-hui, the "Godfather," had intentionally sabotaged Lien Chan to hand Taiwan over to the native-son separatists. The mob pressed against the barricades, hurling eggs, stones, and ink at the building that was supposed to be their sanctuary.

Ma Ying-jeou, pale and exhausted, stepped out to face them. He was the party's rising star, the clean face of the KMT, but tonight he was just another target. An egg smashed against his shoulder. A megaphone amplified the chaotic screams. He tried to speak of unity, of calm, but his voice was drowned out by the fury of a people who felt their country was being stolen. He looked back at the headquarters, his eyes wide with the realization that the party structure had completely collapsed. The police were struggling to hold the line. The KMT was not losing to an external enemy; it was tearing itself apart.

V. The Eulogy (20:00)

The final numbers were etched onto the screen, a digital tombstone for the dynasty.

${FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT.toFixed(1)}%

It was an insult. A number so low it defied logic. Less than 30 percent. Third place. The Kuomintang, the party of Sun Yat-sen and Chiang Kai-shek, had finished third. It was not a defeat; it was a massacre.

Lien Chan walked onto the stage. The room was half-empty now, populated only by the die-hard loyalists and the staff too young or too scared to leave. The air smelled of stale cigarette smoke and damp wool.

He approached the microphone. The cameras flashed, blinding him, capturing every line of exhaustion on his face. He began to read from the prepared statement, but the words felt hollow, like dust in his mouth. He spoke of respecting the democratic process, of the party's long history. But the narrative had already escaped him.

He looked out at the sparse crowd. He looked for the faces of the heavyweights who had promised him the world, but they were gone, likely already making phone calls to the Chen camp or to Soong's people. He was alone. A general without an army. A king without a country.

Outside, the rain intensified, washing away the campaign posters from the gutters of Taipei. The neon lights of the city reflected on the wet asphalt, indifferent to the tragedy unfolding at Ren'ai Road. The fifty-year reign was over. It didn't end with a bang, nor with a whimper, but with the confused, humiliated silence of a man who realized, too late, that the world had moved on without him.

The dynasty has fallen.

`); e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/dumplien.jpg'})]); } // 判定条件：陈水扁获胜(ID 67) 且得票率崩盘(< 27%) -> 回归历史线的沉重结局 if (!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === 67 && FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT < 27) { // 1. 结局文本 e.pages.push(`
MAY 2023 • CATHAY YIPIN BUILDING, TAIPEI

The Long Twilight of the Aristocrat
(世家最后的黄昏)

The tea is still warm, but the room feels colder now that the guests have departed. Mayor Hou Yu-ih (侯友宜)—the man they call the "God Detective" (神探)—has left with the prize he came for: a public letter of support, a blessing from the party patriarch.

Lien Chan sits back in his leather armchair, rubbing his trembling hands. He looks at the empty cup where Hou had sipped his tea. A detective... Lien thinks, a bitter smile touching his lips. Not a scholar, not a diplomat, not a statesman trained in the halls of governance, but a policeman who spent his life chasing criminals in the alleyways.

He remembers Hou's rough, calloused hands shaking his own soft ones. He remembers the heavy Chiayi accent, so different from the refined Mandarin of the old party elite. He remembers how, for years, this "Detective" kept his distance from the KMT, walking a fine line, refusing to aid the party when it was bleeding. And let us not forget—who was the police chief during the investigation of the shooting in 2004? Who told the world there was no conspiracy?

"We must win," Hou had said, his brow furrowed with the pragmatism of a street cop. "For the Republic of China."

Lien had nodded. He had to. The Party has no one else. The "Blue Blood" lineage ended with him. Now, the Kuomintang must rely on this "local hero," this stranger in a blue vest, to save it from oblivion.

His mind drifts back, unbidden, through the fog of years.

1996. He sees himself standing next to Him—Lee Teng-hui. The "First Popularly Elected Vice President." He was the heir apparent, the Prince receiving the mandate. He didn't know then that the King was holding a dagger behind his back.

2000. The rain. The split. The humiliation. ${FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT.toFixed(1)}%. He stares at that number burned into his memory. He remembers the shock on the faces of the party elders. He remembers the jeers from the crowds who flocked to Soong's charisma or A-Bian's fire. That was the year the "KMT Republic" truly died, and he was the captain who went down with the ship.

2004. The noise. The firecrackers... or so he thought. Bang. Bang. March 19th. The "Two Bullets." He remembers the rage he felt that night at the hospital, the crowd at the Ketagalan Boulevard screaming for truth. He was robbed by history. And the man who just left his house... he was part of that history too, wasn't he?

2014. His beloved son, Sean (勝文). He tried to pass the torch, to keep the Lien family legacy alive in the capital. But the "White Force" of Ko Wen-je swept them away. The people didn't want a princeling anymore. They laughed at his son. They called his family "compradors."

And now, 2023. He is old. His body is failing. He has survived cancer, strokes, and political exile. He looks out the window at the Taipei skyline—a city he was born to rule, yet a city that never truly loved him.

Lien Chan closes his eyes. The "God Detective" is out there, campaigning, trying to arrest the decline of a party that is already a ghost. Lien has done his duty. He has given his blessing.

But as the sun sets over the Tamsui River, casting long shadows over the Datun mountains, a single, cold tear traces a path down his wrinkled cheek.

"I have done everything right... so why am I the one sitting in the dark?"

The House Divided

The tragedy of March 18th did not begin with a collapse, but with a cruel and lingering hope. Inside the Kuomintang headquarters on Ren’ai Road, the afternoon was defined not by the silence of the grave, but by the frantic, electric hum of a machine pushing itself to the breaking point. The internal tracking polls at 4:00 PM told a story that was agonizingly close. The "Stability Card" was working. The mobilization of the military villages had held the line. Lien Chan was not collapsing; he was fighting. The mood in the war room was one of desperate calculation: men in shirtsleeves, ties loosened, shouting numbers across the room, believing that the "Iron Vote" would return home at the last second to save the Republic. They weren't fighting to avoid embarrassment; they were fighting to win. Ma Ying-jeou stood by the phones, his voice hoarse from hours of pleading with local faction leaders in the south, trying to stitch together a coalition that was unraveling at the seams. There was a belief, fragile but palpable, that the party’s century-old mandate was bending, but not breaking.

But as night fell and the rain began to lash against the windows of Taipei, the cruel mathematics of democracy began to assert themselves. The television screens flickered with the cold reality of the count. Kaohsiung was lost. Taipei was a three-way deadlock. The numbers for Lien were respectable—far better than the doomsday predictions—but they were haunted by a ghost. Every vote for Lien was shadowed by a vote for James Soong. The former Governor was not fading away; he was standing tall, stripping away a third of the electorate. The KMT was not losing to Chen Shui-bian because the people wanted a revolution; they were losing because the family had taken a knife to its own throat. Jason Hu stared at the monitors, his face tightening as the realization washed over him: the Blue camp commanded a clear majority of the island's votes—sixty percent, perhaps more—but it was a majority sliced perfectly in half. It was a suicide pact written on ballot paper.

By 7:30 PM, the hope had curdled into a bitter, agonizing frustration. The headquarters was not emptying out; it was filling up with a dense, suffocating anger. The party elders didn't flee; they paced the floor like caged tigers, cursing the stubbornness of the split. In the holding room, Lien Chan sat with a posture of rigid defiance. He had done his duty. He had held the center. He had not been humiliated—he had secured a significant portion of the vote, proving his legitimacy. But it wasn't enough. Beside him, Lien Fang-yu looked at the television, where the combined tallies of Lien and Soong dwarfed Chen’s numbers. "We have the numbers," she whispered, her voice trembling with the injustice of it. "We have the people. Why are we losing?" It was the question that would haunt the party for a generation. They were watching a slow-motion train wreck where they were both the conductors and the victims.

The sound from the street changed. It wasn't just the mob screaming for heads; it was the sound of heartbreak. Thousands of supporters gathered in the rain, weeping openly. They weren't angry that Lien was weak; they were furious that the leadership had allowed this fratricide to happen. "United we stand, divided we fall!" someone screamed over a megaphone, the irony cutting through the humid air like a blade. The target of their rage was singular and absolute: Lee Teng-hui. The crowd outside the barricades chanted his name not as a President, but as the architect of their doom. They believed he had engineered this split, playing Lien against Soong to pave the way for Chen. Ma Ying-jeou walked out to the balcony, looking down at the sea of blue flags that were drowning in the green tide. He saw the faces of veterans, of teachers, of civil servants—people who had given everything to the party—now realizing that their loyalty had been weaponized against itself. He didn't face a riot; he faced a wake.

Finally, the result was frozen on the screen: ${FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT.toFixed(1)}%.

It was a number that commanded respect but delivered death. It was not the single-digit shame of a minor party, nor the overwhelming mandate of a victor. It was the "noble defeat"—the most painful kind of all. It signified that the KMT was still alive, still powerful, but fatally decapitated by its own internal war. Lien Chan took the podium, the lights blinding him. He looked out at the room, not with the shame of a failure, but with the grim resolve of a survivor in a ruined city. He spoke of the "pan-Blue majority," a phrase that tasted like ashes. He knew, and everyone in the room knew, that if the two halves had been one, the night would have ended in champagne and fireworks. Instead, it ended in rain and recriminations.

As the cameras flashed, capturing the stoic agony on Lien’s face, the truth settled over the island. The dynasty hadn't fallen because the barbarians breached the gates; it had fallen because the brothers inside opened them to settle a grudge. The Republic of China would wake up tomorrow to a new green sky, not because the blue had faded, but because it had torn itself apart.

`); e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/dumplien2.jpg?v=1765910744835'})]); } // 判定条件：陈水扁获胜(ID 67)且得票率在27%到35%之间 (比史实强，但仍因分裂落败) if (!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === 67 && FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT >= 27 && FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT < 35) { // 1. 结局文本：模拟现代网络深度媒体（如“报导者”或“端传媒”风格） e.pages.push(`
THE STRAIT INSIGHT | 深度评论
2024 ELECTION WATCH

The Mathematics of Suicide: Why the "Ghost of 2000" is Staring at Hou and Ko

In 2000, a strong Lien Chan and a charismatic James Soong handed the presidency to Chen Shui-bian. Twenty-three years later, are the KMT and TPP about to replay the same tragedy for Lai Ching-te?

By Lin Ze-hong (Senior Analyst) Nov 15, 2023

History does not repeat itself, but it often rhymes. As the KMT's Hou Yu-ih and the TPP's Ko Wen-je bicker over polling errors and "3% margins" at the Grand Hyatt, the ghost of the year 2000 is sitting quietly in the corner, laughing.

Younger voters might only remember the KMT's collapse. But the veterans remember the truth of 2000: Lien Chan was not weak.

In that fateful election, Lien Chan commanded the party machine effectively, securing ${FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT.toFixed(1)}% of the vote. He was a formidable force. James Soong, the charismatic defector, was equally powerful. They were two giants, each convinced they were the "true" choice of the majority.

The result? They canceled each other out. Their combined vote share exceeded 60%, yet Chen Shui-bian (A-Bian) walked into the Presidential Office with a minority plurality. It was the perfect crime of political mathematics.

"The lesson of 2000 is brutal: A divided majority is nothing but a losing minority. When two strong candidates fight for the same pie, the third man doesn't need to win; he just needs to wait."

Fast forward to 2023. The parallels are chilling.

Lai Ching-te (DPP) is polling steadily around 35-40%, just like A-Bian did. He has reached his ceiling, but he has a floor of steel. He is sipping tea, watching the "Blue-White" drama unfold, knowing that as long as the opposition remains split, the presidency is his by default.

Hou Yu-ih plays the role of Lien Chan: the establishment candidate, rigid, backed by the organizational muscle of the KMT, but struggling to inspire passion. Ko Wen-je plays the role of Soong: the disruptor, the populist, the one capturing the youth and the disillusioned, convinced that the "Old Party" should yield to him.

They should look at 2004. Four years after the disaster, Lien and Soong swallowed their pride. The Lien-Soong Ticket (國亲合) united the Pan-Blue camp. Despite the controversy of the "Two Bullets," they came within a whisker of unseating an incumbent president. Cooperation made them competitive. Division made them irrelevant.

The voters are tired. The "Non-Green Coalition" (非綠聯盟) holds 60% of the public will, just as it did two decades ago. But public will cannot translate into ballots if there are two boxes to check.

If Hou and Ko walk out of that room without a deal, they are not just betraying their supporters; they are insulting history. They are hand-delivering Taiwan's future to the DPP for another eight years, possibly twelve.

Lien Chan learned this lesson the hard way. Will Hou and Ko learn it in time? Or will we be writing this same article in 2028?

© 2023 The Strait Insight. All rights reserved.

The Stolen Throne

The narrative of the night was supposed to be one of redemption. Inside the Kuomintang headquarters on Ren’ai Road, the afternoon mood was not one of fear, but of a galvanized, combative energy. The "Iron Vote" had not rusted; it had returned home. At 4:00 PM, the internal reports showed a massive surge. The strategic voting campaign had worked. The military villages, the civil servants, the deep-blue loyalists—they had all abandoned James Soong to rally behind the party flag. Lien Chan was performing like a true heavyweight, commanding numbers that, in any normal election, would guarantee a landslide. The staff moved with the aggressive confidence of soldiers who know they are outgunning the enemy. They weren't just defending a legacy; they were crushing a rebellion. Ma Ying-jeou, eyes bright with intensity, was on the phone with precinct captains, shouting confirmations: "We have the numbers. The prodigal sons have returned. We are going to win this."

But as the evening wore on, the cruelest paradox of democracy began to unfold on the giant screens. The map was not turning Green; it was a patchwork of Blue dominance, yet the total sum remained agonizingly short. Chen Shui-bian was leading, but by the thinnest of margins—a razor’s edge. The culprit was staring at them from the bottom of the screen. James Soong, now clearly relegated to a distant third, was refusing to vanish completely. He was no longer a contender; he was a spoiler. A ghost haunting the machine. Every percentage point Soong clung to was a drop of blood drained from Lien’s victory. The mood in the room shifted from confidence to a boiling, white-hot fury. Jason Hu slammed his hand onto a desk, a rare break in his diplomat’s demeanor. "He can’t win!" Hu hissed, staring at Soong’s tally. "He knows he can’t win! He is just staying in to kill us. It’s suicide bombing."

By 8:00 PM, the tragedy was mathematically undeniable. The headquarters was not a funeral home; it was a powder keg. The KMT elite, usually so composed, were openly cursing. They saw the "Taiwan Miracle" slipping away not because the people rejected the KMT, but because one man’s ego stood in the way of the collective survival. Lien Chan sat in the holding room, his face flushed not with shame, but with indignation. He had done everything right. He had consolidated the base. He had proven his legitimacy. He had secured a massive mandate from the people. Beside him, Lien Fang-yu gripped her handbag until her knuckles turned white. She wasn't sad; she was livid. "They are stealing it," she said, her voice trembling with rage. "We are the majority. Look at the numbers! If you add the Blues together, we crush them. How can a minority rule us?"

The crowd outside did not disperse in defeat; they gathered in a riotous fury. But this time, their anger was precise. They weren't just shouting at Lee Teng-hui; they were burning effigies of James Soong. "Sinner of the Nation!" they chanted. "Historical Criminal!" The narrative on the street was clear: Lien Chan had fought a hero’s battle, bringing the party back from the brink, only to be stabbed in the back by a former comrade. Ma Ying-jeou stepped onto the balcony, looking out at a sea of supporters who had voted correctly, who had done their duty, but were being punished regardless. He felt the bitterness of the rain on his face. It was the bitterness of a runner who breaks the world record but finishes second because someone tripped him at the finish line.

The final result flashed on the screen, a number that mocked justice: ${FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT.toFixed(1)}%.

It was a massive number. A number that represented millions of voices calling for stability. Combined with the scraps Soong had taken, the Pan-Blue camp held a supermajority of the island's will. Yet, the presidency belonged to Chen. Lien Chan walked onto the stage, not as a loser, but as a martyr. The applause was thunderous, defiant, prolonged. It was the sound of a party that knew it hadn't been beaten—it had been robbed. Lien spoke with a gravity that silenced the room. He did not apologize. He did not bow his head. He spoke of the "True Majority" and the "distortion of democracy." As he left the podium, the air was thick with the promise of vengeance. The dynasty had fallen, yes, but it had not collapsed from within. It had been murdered. And as the KMT looked at the Green flags waving in the distance, they knew exactly who held the knife.

The Palace Coup

The rain that lashed against the bulletproof glass of the Kuomintang headquarters on Ren'ai Road did not wash away the sins of the evening; it merely amplified the silence inside. It was a heavy, suffocating silence—the kind that hangs in the air after a guillotine blade has fallen, before the crowd realizes the king is actually dead.

Tonight was supposed to be the validation of the System. The Party Machine, a beast fed on fifty years of patronage and iron-fisted organization, had roared into gear to crush the rebellion. But as the numbers poured in from the counting stations, the beast lay dying, dismantled not by the separatists of the DPP, but by its own exiled son. James Soong—the traitor, the outcast, the man Lee Teng-hui had tried to erase from history—had not just survived. He had conquered.

In the center of the VIP holding room, Lien Chan stood like a statue carved from salt, dissolving under the humidity of defeat. He stared at the television screens, where the map of Taiwan was being painted in a defiant, shocking Orange. The "Blue Sky" had not turned Green; it had burned itself into the color of the setting sun. Lien looked at his own tally, a number so pitiful it felt like a clerical error: ${FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT.toFixed(1)}%.

The humiliation was total. Around them, the atmosphere shifted from panic to a grotesque Darwinism. The opportunists were already moving. In the back corridors, the mid-level bureaucrats and the heads of the local factions—the "wind-vanes" who had sworn blood oaths to the KMT only yesterday—were frantically making phone calls. They weren't calling to offer condolences; they were calling to negotiate surrender. The powerful Speaker of the Legislature, the heavyweights of the irrigation associations, and the clan leaders of Central Taiwan... they were stripping off their KMT lapel pins with practiced ease. They were pragmatists, worshippers of power, and tonight, the mandate of heaven had clearly passed to the man in the Orange jacket. The rats weren't just fleeing the sinking ship; they were swimming vigorously toward the new captain.

But for others, tonight was not about survival; it was about vengeance. From the shadows of political exile, the ghosts of the "Non-Mainstream Faction" were emerging, tasting a sweetness they had been denied for a decade. The old generals, the ideologues, and the conservatives whom Lee Teng-hui had systematically purged, marginalized, and mocked as "dinosaurs" throughout the 90s—they were laughing now. They saw the collapse of Lien Chan not as a tragedy, but as divine retribution.

"The tyranny of the Mainstream is over," an old party elder whispered, his eyes gleaming with vindictive ecstasy. They believed that Lee had destroyed the soul of the party to build his own kingdom; tonight, they watched that kingdom crumble into dust. Soong’s victory was their proxy war won. The suppression was broken. The "Lee Teng-hui Era" hadn't ended with a majestic sunset, but with a violent peasant revolt led by his own former lieutenant.

Outside, the sound of the mob was changing. It wasn't the despair of defeat; it was the fury of vindication. The KMT supporters gathering at the gates were not mourning; they were rioting against the Central Standing Committee. They waved flags, but they weren't chanting for Lien.

"Lee Teng-hui, Step Down! You tried to kill Soong! You killed the Party instead!"

Ma Ying-jeou stood by the window, looking down at the chaos. He looked terrified. He had been the good soldier, the one who attacked Soong’s integrity on command. Now, the man he had demonized was the President-Elect. Ma knew that the mob outside didn't just want Lee’s head; they wanted the heads of everyone who had collaborated in the purge.

Lien Chan walked towards the podium to deliver his concession speech, a ghost walking through a graveyard of his own making. He opened his mouth to speak of "respecting democracy," but the words tasted of ashes. The dynasty hadn't fallen to the barbarians at the gate. It had been overthrown by the brother it left out in the cold, while the cousins inside unlocked the doors and cheered for the invader.

`); e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/zhutou.jpg?v=1765911526254'})]); } // 判定条件：连战(ID 68)且得票率崩盘(低于27%，符合历史23%甚至更低的情况) 宋楚瑜获胜 if (!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === 69 && FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT < 27) { // 1. 设置结局文本 e.pages.push(`
INSIDER GAMBLING REPORT JAN 10, 2020 • KAOHSIUNG UNDERGROUND

The Bookie's Verdict: Why the "Blue Ghost" Pays Nothing

On the eve of the 2020 Election, the odds tell the brutal truth: It's an Orange vs. Green war. The KMT is just a zombie looking for a grave.

DPP (Lai Ching-te): 1賠1.85 (PK盤 - Slight Edge)

PFP (Terry Gou): 1賠2.10 (Strong Contender)

KMT (Eric Chu): 封盤 (OFF THE BOARD) -> 1賠50.00 (Prop Bet Only)

Asking a Zutou (bookie) in Chiayi about Eric Chu (朱立倫) is like asking for snow in July. The old man spat out his beetle nut juice and laughed: "Why waste ink on a corpse?"

The numbers don't lie. The "Blue" money has long since turned Orange. In the underground parlors from Yunlin to Pingtung, the bets are flying on whether Lai holds the fort or if the Tycoon Terry Gou brings the Presidency back to the Soong Dynasty. But the KMT? The party that ruled China?

They are polling at 12%. Twelve.

It all goes back to The Year of the Crash (2000). I was a runner back then. I remember the faces of the KMT elders when Lien Chan—the man who had everything, money, machine, legitimacy—couldn't even break 27%. He didn't just lose; he was humiliated. The voters looked at his stiffness, his disconnect, and they ran to Soong's charisma or A-Bian's fire.

That night, the KMT didn't just lose power; they lost their soul. The Mainlanders and the urban elites realized Lien was a sinking ship, so they packed their bags for James Soong's People First Party. The PFP became the real defender of the ROC. The KMT? It was left to the vultures.

We watched Wang Jin-pyng (王金平) try to salvage the wreckage in '08 and '12. He turned the KMT into a club for local factions—a "Taiwanese KMT" that cared more about irrigation association chairmanships than the Presidency. They became the "Third Party," a joke.

Now, look at poor Eric Chu. He's one of the last "Mainlander elites" stupid enough to stay on a sinking ship, begging for votes in a party that speaks Minnan and smells like old money and defeat. The street logic is simple: "Dump Chu, Save Gou" (棄朱保郭). If you bet on Blue tomorrow, you don't just lose your money; you lose your dignity.

Prediction: The KMT dissolves within the decade. The Orange Dawn continues, or the Green Sky solidifies. But the Blue? The Blue is the color of bruises.

`); // 2. 图片变更：建议使用一张朱立伦孤独站在空旷舞台，或者一张显示KMT民调极低的图表，背景是热闹的郭台铭/赖清德造势 // 这里使用一张象征性的“蓝营陨落”图 e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/1456469863720985.jpg?v=1765893750716'})]); // 3. 音乐设置：选择一种充满悬疑、紧张感，带有都市霓虹感的背景音乐，模拟地下赌盘氛围 if (songChange != 1) { songChange = 1 const noir_playlist = new Playlist(); const noir_song = new Song( "Dancing girl", "Luo Da-you", "https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/JI4U4FEprE_4Y9MGO6aSphtzdbcFyp0dayMXhR-J92TD_cL7srMprrRCmiXofVn2Q6V8-AszKfJUihM", "https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/%E8%88%9E%E5%A5%B3%20-%20Lo%20Ta-yu%20(youtube).mp3?v=1765893957529" ); noir_playlist.addSong(noir_song, 0); changePlaylist(noir_playlist); } } // 判定条件：宋楚瑜(ID 69) 且 得票率 < 27% (虽然得票率低，但在本剧本设定中设为获胜或特定分支) if (!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === 69 && FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT < 27) { // 1. 设置结局页面内容 e.pages.push(`

List of Presidents of the Republic of China

Term President Assumed Office Left Office Party Vice President Election
6 Chiang Ching-kuo 蔣經國 (1910–1988) 20 May 1978 13 January 1988 Kuomintang Hsieh Tung-min 6 (1978)

The House Divided Stands... Barely

The atmosphere inside the Kuomintang headquarters on Ren'ai Road was not one of panic, but of a profound, intellectual frustration. It was the feeling of a grandmaster who has played a perfect game of chess, only to realize he was sitting at the wrong table. The rain outside continued to fall, blurring the neon lights of a Taipei that now belonged to James Soong.

Lien Chan stood tall. He did not look like the crushed man of the doomsday scenarios. His tally on the screen read ${FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT.toFixed(1)}%. It was a respectable number. It was a number that proved the Party Machine still had teeth, that the "Iron Vote" of the military villages and civil servants had largely obeyed the order to hold the line. The KMT had not collapsed. It had fought bravely.

And that was exactly the tragedy.

"We were too strong," Ma Ying-jeou murmured, staring at the split-screen showing the celebrations at Soong’s headquarters and the subdued disappointment at Chen Shui-bian’s rally. "If we had been weaker, the voters would have abandoned us to save Soong. If we had been stronger, we would have crushed him. Instead, we were strong enough to spoil the victory, but not strong enough to claim it."

The specter of Strategic Voting (弃保) hung over the room like a ghost that never arrived. For months, the pundits had predicted that voters would "Dump Lien to Save Soong" or "Dump Soong to Save Lien." But tonight, the voters had been paralyzed by loyalty. The Blue camp had turned out in massive, overwhelming numbers—perhaps 60% or 70% of the island voted for a Blue candidate—but they had sliced that majority perfectly down the middle.

Jason Hu looked at the numbers coming from the Green camp. Chen Shui-bian had been marginalized, squeezed out by the massive turnout of the Pan-Blue civil war. "Look at Chen," Hu pointed out, a dry, cynical smile playing on his lips. "The DPP is in shock. They thought our division would hand them the presidency. Instead, our division was so energized that we simply drowned them out. We stopped Independence... by electing a Dictator."

It was a bitter consolation. The KMT had successfully blocked the "Green Terror," but in doing so, they had lost the mandate of Heaven to their own "Prodigal Son."

Lien Fang-yu maintained her composure, her eyes scanning the room. She saw the local faction leaders—who had hesitated to defect because Lien’s polling numbers remained decent—now looking at their shoes in regret. They had bet on the tortoise because it looked steady, only to see the hare cross the finish line battered but victorious.

"We kept the soul of the party," Lien Chan said quietly, preparing his statement. He believed it. By refusing to bow to Soong, he had preserved the KMT's orthodox lineage. He hadn't allowed the party to be hostilely taken over without a fight.

But as he walked out to the podium, the applause was polite, not passionate. The supporters knew the truth. The "Blue Camp" was now a two-headed dragon, and the head that wore the crown was the one they had tried to cut off. The KMT had survived the night, but they were no longer the rulers. They were now the "Junior Partner" in a kingdom they built. The dynasty hadn't fallen; it had been divorced, and the other parent had won custody of the country.

`); e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/lienbai.png?v=1765911568339'})]); } // 判定条件：连战(ID 68)且得票率在27%到35%之间（体面落败，保存了元气但输掉了政权） if (!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === 69 && FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT >= 27 && FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT < 35) { // 1. 设置结局文本 e.pages.push(`

January 10, 2020 • Da'an District, Taipei

The War at the Dinner Table: Blue, Orange, and the Green Ghost

The chopstick rest flew across the table before the soup was even served. It wasn't about the food. It was never about the food.

"You are handing the country to Lai Ching-te!" my uncle shouted, his face flushing red, pointing a trembling finger at my cousin. "Han Kuo-yu (韓國瑜) is the nominee of the ruling party! He is the successor of President Ma! How can you betray the Party?"

My cousin, a tech executive in Hsinchu, didn't back down. He slammed his hand on the table. "The KMT is dead brained, Uncle! Han is a clown! Look at the polls! Terry Gou (郭台銘) is the only one who understands the economy. He is the true heir to the Soong Era!"

I sat there, picking at my rice, listening to the history of our fractured nation being re-litigated for the thousandth time. It always comes back to 2000.

"Lien Chan got ${FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT.toFixed(1)}% that year!" my grandfather muttered from his chair, his eyes cloudy. "He didn't collapse. He held the line. But Soong... Soong took the presidency."

Yes, James Soong (宋楚瑜) won in 2000. For eight years, the People First Party (PFP) ruled. They say it was a golden age of stability. But the KMT never forgave them. The split allowed the DPP's Frank Hsieh (謝長廷) to sneak in for a single term in 2008. Those four years of Green rule terrified the Blues enough to unite behind Ma Ying-jeou in 2012.

But now? Ma is stepping down after eight years, and the truce is over. The "Tri-Polar" nightmare is back.

Latest TVBS Poll:
DPP (Lai Ching-te): 34%
PFP (Terry Gou): 31%
KMT (Han Kuo-yu): 29%
Margin of error: ±3%

"Strategic voting (棄保) won't work this time," my aunt sighed, looking at the TV screen where rallies for all three candidates were splitting the screen. " The KMT base loves Han's nationalism. The PFP base loves Gou's pragmatism. Neither will yield."

"Then we die together," my uncle said grimly. "Just like we almost did in 2000. Just like we did in 2008."

Outside the window, the campaign trucks were passing by. One blasted the PFP anthem, the other waved the KMT flag, and somewhere in the distance, I could hear the cheering from the DPP headquarters. The Green camp doesn't need to fight; they just need to watch us destroy ourselves.

The plates are broken. The family is divided. And tomorrow, Taiwan chooses between the Merchant, the Populist, and the Doctor.

The Vanishing of Green

The night of March 18th was not written in Green ink, as the pundits had predicted for months. Instead, it was written in a chaotic clash of Blue and Orange, a binary star system that had swallowed the rest of the galaxy whole. Inside the Kuomintang headquarters on Ren'ai Road, the mood was one of existential confusion. The "Three-Kingdoms" war they had prepared for had evaporated. Chen Shui-bian, the nightmare of the establishment, had been rendered irrelevant.

Jason Hu stood before the wall of monitors, his brow furrowed in disbelief. He pointed at the data coming from Tainan and Kaohsiung—traditional strongholds of the opposition. "Look at the numbers," he whispered, his voice tinged with a strange mixture of awe and horror. "The DPP vote has collapsed. They aren't voting for Chen. They are voting for us."

It was the ultimate irony. The fear of a James Soong presidency—a fear of a return to authoritarian strongman rule—had terrified the Green electorate so profoundly that they had abandoned their own candidate to support Lien Chan. The "Dump Chen to Save Lien" (棄扁保連) effect had actually happened.

And yet, it was not enough.

"He is fighting the entire establishment," Ma Ying-jeou said, looking out at the rain-slicked streets. "He is fighting the Party, the Palace, and even the tactical voters of the DPP... and he is crushing them all."

In hindsight, the signs had been etched into the sky for months. The opinion polls had not just favored Soong; they had anointed him. The KMT had fired their ultimate weapon—the Chung Hsing Bills Case (興票案)—a scandal designed to destroy a politician’s financial integrity overnight. It was supposed to be the silver bullet. Yet, the accusations bounced off his armor like pebbles against a tank. The voters saw the scandal not as corruption, but as persecution. Every attack launched by the Party Central only fed the narrative of the lone warrior standing against a rigged system. The mudslinging didn't bury him; it calcified his support into something unbreakable.

Lien Fang-yu sat in silence, her hands folded. She realized the gravity of the situation. "We became the candidate of 'Anyone But Soong,'" she said softly. "And the people looked at 'Anyone,' and they still chose Soong."

The television showed the scenes at Chen Shui-bian’s headquarters. It was a ghost town. The "Son of Taiwan" had been reduced to a single-digit footnote. The concept of "Taiwan Independence" had not been defeated at the ballot box; it had been ignored, rendered obsolete by a civil war over the soul of the Republic of China.

Lien Chan stepped up to the podium. He had lost, but not because of a split. He had lost despite a consolidation. He represented the combined weight of the KMT machine and the anti-Soong resistance, and he had still been thrown aside. As he conceded, the roar from the streets was deafening. It was the sound of a new hegemony. The KMT was no longer the ruler, and the DPP was no longer the opposition. They were both now just debris in the wake of the Soong Dynasty.

`); e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/4d497ede-4e2e-48d2-a1d4-0d5b034d7290.jpg?v=1765912020873'})]); } // 判定条件：宋楚瑜(ID 69)且得票率 >= 35% (亲民党大胜，确立两蓝对决格局，民进党泡沫化) if (!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === 69 && FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT >= 35) { e.pages.push(`

The Eternal Mandate

March 18, 2000 — The Restoration of the Gold Dynasty

The rain that had threatened to dampen the spirits of Taipei had ceased, seemingly by a command from the Central Standing Committee. Above the Kuomintang headquarters on Ren'ai Road, the clouds parted to reveal a moon that looked less like a celestial body and more like a silver coin minted solely for the pleasure of the ruling party. Inside, the air was not thick with tension; it was intoxicatingly sweet, heavy with the scent of expensive orchids, Cuban cigars, and the palpable, vibrating energy of absolute power.

This was not a campaign headquarters anymore. It was the throne room of an Empire that had just reminded its subjects why it ruled.

Lien Chan stood before the floor-to-ceiling windows of the VIP suite, looking down at the city that lay prostrate at his feet. His reflection in the glass was superimposed over the neon lights of the capital. He adjusted his silk tie, a smile of serene, terrifying arrogance playing on his lips. For months, the pundits had called him stiff, uncharismatic, a rich boy out of touch with the common man. They had said he was riding Lee Teng-hui's coattails. They had said the "Storm of the Century" was coming.

Lien chuckled, a low, dry sound. Let them talk. The numbers on the giant screen behind him were not just a victory; they were a massacre.

${FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT.toFixed(1)}%

Forty-five percent. In a three-way race. It was unheard of. It was a statistical impossibility that the Party had made possible through the sheer, brute force of its machinery. The "Iron Vote" had turned out with the discipline of the Imperial Guard. The business tycoons had fallen in line. The local factions, greased by the promise of continued prosperity, had delivered every village, every temple, every farm.

"The rebellion is crushed," a voice boomed. Lee Teng-hui walked into the room, his face flushed with the triumph of a grandmaster who has checkmated two opponents simultaneously. The President—the "Godfather"—clapped Lien on the shoulder with a force that would have staggered a lesser man. "They thought they could split us. They thought the people wanted change. Bah! The people want a King, and tonight, we gave them two."

The room erupted in polite, sycophantic laughter. The "traitors" had been dealt with. James Soong, the man who dared to challenge the orthodoxy, had been obliterated. The Chung Hsing Bills Case had done its work, painting him not as a hero, but as a thief. The reports from Soong’s headquarters described a scene of weeping and wailing, a funeral for a political career that was now buried under tons of KMT propaganda. And Chen Shui-bian? The "Son of Taiwan"? He had been reduced to a noise in the background, a radical curiosity that the stable, prosperous middle class had rejected in horror. The "Status Quo" was not just maintained; it was cemented for another generation.

Lien Fang-yu glided through the room like a queen, her smile dazzling and triumphant. She accepted bouquets of flowers from the wives of the conglomerates, her eyes shining with the vindication of the aristocracy. "They said we were too old-fashioned," she was heard saying to the wife of Vincent Siew. "But fashion changes. Class is permanent."

In the corner, the younger guard—Ma Ying-jeou, Jason Hu—were huddled together, looking at the breakdown of the votes. Even they, the supposed reformers, were seduced by the scale of the victory.

"It’s a mandate from Heaven," Ma whispered, his usual caution dissolving into the intoxication of the night. "We haven't just won an election. We've proven that the KMT is Taiwan. There is no alternative. The DPP is dead. Soong is dead. There is only the Party."

"We own the narrative now," Hu added, swirling his wine. "We control the cross-strait dialogue. We control the economy. We control the history books. Who is left to challenge us? No one."

It was a dangerous, heady brew of hubris. They believed, in that moment, that the "Golden Decade" would stretch into a "Golden Century." They believed that the island was their personal estate, managed by their wisdom and protected by their wealth. The corruption, the "Black Gold," the authoritarian legacy—none of it mattered. The voters had seen it all and said: "More, please."

Lien Chan walked out onto the balcony to address the sea of supporters. The crowd below was not a riotous mob; it was a disciplined ocean of Blue flags, waving in perfect unison. A roar went up—not of anger, but of adoration for the system that kept them fed and safe.

Lien raised his hands. He did not look like a servant of the people. He looked like the CEO of a monopoly that had just acquired its last competitor.

"My fellow citizens," Lien’s voice boomed over the loudspeakers, amplified to god-like proportions. "Tonight, you have chosen the path of righteousness. You have rejected the chaos of the separatists and the greed of the traitors. You have chosen stability. You have chosen prosperity. You have chosen Us."

He paused, letting the cheers wash over him. In his mind, he saw the future. He saw a seamless transition of power, from Lee to him, and eventually, perhaps to Ma. A lineage of technocrats and elites, ruling benevolently over a grateful populace. He saw the reunification talks proceeding on his terms. He saw the world acknowledging the KMT as the eternal steward of Chinese democracy.

He did not see the rot beneath the floorboards. He did not see that total victory breeds total complacency. He did not see that by crushing the opposition so completely, he had removed the only mirror that could show the Party its own ugly reflection.

But tonight, there were no mirrors. There was only the gold confetti raining down like manna from heaven, the popping of champagne corks that sounded like cannon fire, and the unshakable, arrogant certainty that the Sun would never set on the Blue Sky.

The Dynasty is not just safe.
The Dynasty is Immortal.

`); e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/lienfangyu.jpg?v=1765912467589'})]); } if (!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === 68 && FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT >= 45) { // 1. 结局文本：亚马逊书籍页面风格 e.pages.push(`
Amazon Deliver to Taipei 100 Cart (0)
Books > Politics & Social Sciences > Asian Politics > The KMT Era

THE ETERNAL BLUE SKY

How the KMT Built the World's Most Resilient Democracy

Harvard University Press

The Eternal Blue Sky: The Kuomintang's Hegemony Since 2000 (Hardcover)

by Prof. Kharis Templeman (Author), Dr. Nathan Batto (Editor)
★★★★☆ 4.7 out of 5 stars | 1,450 ratings
$32.50
In Stock.

Book Description

Why does Taiwan's Kuomintang (KMT) never lose? In this definitive history, scholars analyze the "System of 2000"—the political realignment that allowed the KMT to surpass Mexico's PRI and Japan's LDP as the most successful dominant party in democratic history.

The book traces the lineage of the "Neo-KMT" dynasty:

  • Lien Chan (2000-2008): The Architect. His crushing victory in 2000 (${FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT.toFixed(1)}% of the vote) shattered the opposition. He established the "Great Compromise," freezing the independence debate in favor of rapid economic integration.
  • Ma Ying-jeou (2008-2016): The Administrator. Known for the Golden Era of cross-strait trade and the 2015 "Ma-Xi Meeting" in Taipei.
  • Tsai Ing-wen (2016-2024): The Reformer. (Key Chapter). The book explores how the former technocrat rose through the KMT ranks to become the first female President, representing the party's "Localization Wing" (本土派) and neutralizing the DPP by adopting their social policies under the Blue flag.
  • Eric Chu (2024-Present): The Technocrat. Continuing the legacy with Premier Chiang Wan-an groomed as the next successor.

Through interviews with party elders and declassified documents, The Eternal Blue Sky reveals how the KMT transformed from a Leninist-style party into a catch-all election machine that has ruled Taiwan for over 80 uninterrupted years.

Top reviews from the United States

John Mearsheimer
★★★★★ Realism at its finest

The chapter on Lien Chan's "Defensive Realism" in 2000 is masterclass. By crushing the independence movement early, the KMT prevented a war in the Pacific. A stable Taiwan under one-party rule was exactly what Washington and Beijing needed.

TaiwanWatcher99
★★★☆☆ A bit too apologetic to the regime?

The author praises President Tsai (KMT) for her progressive reforms, but glosses over the fact that there is no viable opposition party left. The DPP has been reduced to a 10% fringe group since the 2004 reforms. Is it really a democracy if the Blues always win?

HistoryBuff
★★★★★ Fascinating "What If" turned reality

I grew up in the timeline where Chen Shui-bian won in 2000... oh wait, that was just a nightmare I had. Long live the Republic! This book perfectly explains how the KMT absorbed the Lee Teng-hui legacy.

The Unexpected Landslide

The champagne corks were popping before the final count was even read, the sharp pop echoing like gunfire in the jubilant air of the KMT headquarters. But this was not the rehearsed celebration of an arrogant empire; it was the giddy, hysterical laughter of men who had been holding their breath for six months and finally exhaled.

At 4:00 PM, the internal mood had been one of nervous discipline. Ma Ying-jeou had been pacing the floor, clutching polling data that showed a statistical dead heat, terrified that James Soong’s grassroots charisma or Chen Shui-bian’s momentum would crack the "Stability" firewall. The strategy team had prepared two speeches: one for a narrow victory, and one for a dignified defeat.

They never had to use either.

As the numbers rolled in, the room transformed from a war room into a carnival. The result was not a scrap; it was a rout. ${FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT.toFixed(1)}%.

"I don't believe it," Jason Hu kept saying, shaking his head with a wide, incredulous grin. He slapped a campaign aide on the back, perhaps a little too hard. "We underestimated them. We underestimated the voters! The Silent Majority... they weren't just silent. They were waiting."

The sheer scale of the victory was shocking. In a three-way race, breaking the 40% barrier was supposed to be mathematically impossible. Yet, the "Iron Vote" had turned out in an avalanche, and the swing voters—fearing the unpredictability of Soong and the radicalism of Chen—had flocked to the KMT in a last-minute stampede. The "Dump-Save" effect had worked beyond their wildest dreams.

Lien Chan stood in the center of the room, looking less like a statesman and more like a man who had just won the lottery. His usual stoic, stiff demeanor had melted away. He was beaming, shaking hands with a vigor that surprised everyone. He turned to Lien Fang-yu, who was laughing, wiping tears of sheer relief from her eyes.

"They told us we were boring," Lien said, his voice light and energetic. "They told us we were yesterday's men. Well, it seems the people prefer boring. It seems the people prefer Yesterday over a dangerous Tomorrow."

Even President Lee Teng-hui, the inscrutable "Godfather," seemed pleasantly surprised. He walked into the room not with his usual stern authority, but with a relaxed, almost grandfatherly air. He looked at the map—painted a deep, solid Blue from north to south—and nodded.

"The people are wiser than the pundits," Lee said, taking a glass of wine. "We worried about the storm, but the people built us a shelter."

The specter of James Soong, which had haunted their nightmares for a year, had turned out to be a paper tiger. The fear that he would split the party and hand the election to Chen had proven unfounded. Instead, the KMT machine had simply ground him down, and the voters, when faced with the moment of truth, had returned to the mother ship.

Ma Ying-jeou loosened his tie—a rare sight. He looked at the cheering crowd outside, a sea of Blue flags that stretched down Ren'ai Road. "We thought we were fighting for our lives," he confessed to a junior staffer. "But the war was over before it began. We just didn't know it."

The night ended not with the heavy burden of ruling, but with the lightness of a bullet dodged. They had expected a mandate of inches; they had been given a mandate of miles. The KMT was not just alive; it was revitalized, fueled by a victory that was as sweet as it was surprising.

`); e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/liensiew.jpg?v=1765912756686'})]); } if (!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === 68 && FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT > 35 && FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT <= 40) { e.pages.push(`

The Eye of the Needle

The air in the KMT headquarters did not smell of victory; it smelled of stale coffee, sweat, and adrenaline. For six agonizing hours, the numbers on the screen had swung like a pendulum in a gale, tilting toward James Soong, then swinging toward Chen Shui-bian, before finally, agonizingly, settling back to the center.

There were no cheers when the networks finally called the race at 9:15 PM. There was only a collective, shuddering exhale. Men in expensive suits loosened their ties and slumped against the walls, looking less like conquerors and more like survivors of a shipwreck who had just washed ashore.

${FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT.toFixed(1)}%.

It was not a mandate. It was barely a plurality. But in the brutal mathematics of a three-way war, it was enough.

Lien Chan sat in the private holding room, wiping his forehead with a handkerchief. He looked drained. The weight of the dynasty had almost crushed him. He knew how close it had been. If Soong had taken one more industrial district, or if Chen had mobilized one more sector in the south, the house of cards would have collapsed.

Beside him, Vincent Siew (蕭萬長) leaned against the heavy oak desk, studying the breakdown of the vote. The "Smiling Siew" lived up to his nickname, but tonight, the smile was tight, tired, the expression of a man who had just defused a bomb with seconds to spare.

"We stopped the bleeding," Siew said quietly, tapping the map. "The local business leaders stayed with us. It wasn't pretty, but the native vote held just enough to block the others."

Lien looked at his running mate with a rare expression of genuine gratitude. They all knew the truth: without Siew’s "Commoner Premier" image, without his tireless campaigning to reassure the local factions and the SME owners, the KMT would have lost. The "Lien-Siew" ticket had not won because of charisma; it had won because it was the heavy anchor that kept the ship from drifting into the radical storms of Independence or the unpredictable waters of Soong’s populism.

"It was an ugly win," Ma Ying-jeou admitted, standing by the window, watching the rain lessen. "We govern with a minority of the popular vote. The Legislature will be a battlefield. Soong’s people are furious, and Chen’s people are heartbroken. We are encircled."

"But we govern," Siew corrected him firmly. "That is the only thing that matters. We bought time. We bought stability."

The television showed the angry crowds at the other two headquarters. The opposition combined had polled over 60% of the vote. The KMT had thread the needle, slipping through the gap created by the mutual destruction of their enemies. It was a victory of geometry, not popularity.

Lien Fang-yu squeezed her husband’s hand. She didn't say anything about glory or history. She simply said, "It's over."

Lien Chan straightened his back, putting on the mask of the President-Elect. He prepared to go out and speak to the nation. He would talk about unity, about healing the wounds of the election. But as he walked toward the stage, he knew the truth. They hadn't won the hearts of the nation; they had simply survived the night. The dynasty stood, but its foundations were cracked, held together by the pragmatic smile of Vincent Siew and the merciless luck of the draw.
