The Stolen Night

There was no confetti. There was no champagne. Inside the KMT headquarters on Ren'ai Road, the mood was closer to a bunker during a losing war than a victory celebration. The air conditioning hummed, but it could not drown out the sound that terrified everyone in the room: the rhythmic, thunderous crashing of thousands of bodies against the razor-wire barricades outside.

The television screens were not showing a map of a unified Taiwan. They were showing split-screens of chaos. In front of the Central Election Commission, protesters were burning tires. In Kaohsiung, riot police were clashing with angry voters screaming "Black Box!" (作票). The count had stalled, stuttered, and then, in a moment that would be debated for decades, tipped infinitesimally in favor of the ruling party.

${FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT.toFixed(1)}%

It was a number so low, so mathematically fragile, that it felt like an insult to democracy. Less than 35 percent. Nearly two-thirds of the island had voted against Lien Chan. He had won not by a mandate, but by a statistical accident—or, as the mobs outside were screaming, by a crime.

Lien Chan sat in the deepest recess of the VIP suite, far away from the windows. He looked pale, his hands trembling slightly as he held a cup of lukewarm tea. He was the President-Elect, but he felt like a fugitive.

"They are demanding a recount," Ma Ying-jeou said, his voice tight with anxiety. He was on the phone with the legal team, his usual polished demeanor cracking under the strain. "James Soong is refusing to concede. He claims there were irregularities in Yunlin. He claims the lights went out in the counting stations. His lawyers are already filing for an annulment of the election."

"Let them file," snapped a party elder, though his eyes darted nervously to the door. "We have the certificate. Possession is nine-tenths of the law."

Vincent Siew (蕭萬長) stood by the television, watching the breaking news. Chen Shui-bian’s supporters were joining forces with Soong’s. For the first time, Green and Orange flags were waving together, united by a common fury against the Blue establishment. "This isn't an election anymore," Siew murmured grimly. "It's a siege."

Lien Fang-yu looked at her husband with wide, fearful eyes. "Can we even go out there?" she asked. "Is it safe?"

Nobody answered her immediately. The roar from the street grew louder. "Election Invalid! Down with the Fraud!" The accusations were flying wildly—phantom ballots, stuffed boxes, magical vote dumps in the final ten minutes. Whether true or false, the perception had already solidified: The KMT had lost the trust of the people, so they had simply manufactured the result.

Lien Chan stood up, straightening his suit jacket. He had to address the nation. He had to pretend that this was a normal victory, that the burning tires and the lawsuits and the screaming millions did not exist. He had to accept the mandate, even if it was a poisoned chalice.

"We follow the law," Lien said, his voice sounding hollow in the quiet room. "The numbers are the numbers."

But as he walked toward the secure exit, flanked by nervous security guards, he knew that tonight was not the end. The KMT had held onto power, but the cost was the legitimacy of the Republic itself. They were not entering a Golden Age; they were entering a season of riots, recounts, and endless suspicion. The Dynasty had survived, but it was now a prisoner in its own palace, guarding a throne that everyone else believed was stolen.

`); e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/dsadadasda.jpg?v=1765913366469'})]); } //阿辉养了第二条狗 if (!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === LIEN_ID && e.LeeTengHuiAttacks >= 5 && e.PoliticalReformPromise <= 0) { // 1. THE FORMOSA VANGUARD | EDITORIAL

September 19, 2020 • New York • "The Voice of True Taiwan"

The Stolen Nation: Why We Weep for A-Bian, and Why the "KMT Republic" Must Burn

Lee Teng-hui is dead, but his greatest sin lives on: he taught the colonial oppressors how to speak Taiwanese, leaving the true sons of the soil to rot in obscurity.

They call it a "National Funeral." We call it a masquerade ball for the usurpers. As the rain fell on Wuzhi Mountain, we saw the KMT elites bowing to the man who saved their regime. But our eyes were looking for a ghost—the ghost of 2000, the ghost of a Taiwan that never was.

Where was Chen Shui-bian (陳水扁)? The man who should have been our Moses? The "Son of Taiwan" who ignited the hopes of millions in the 1990s? He sits in a small law office in Tainan today, a forgotten footnote, a tragic figure erased from history by Lien Chan's "soft coup" two decades ago.

In 2000, we were so close. We could smell the dawn of independence. But Lien Chan, that cunning inheritor of the Black Gold machine, did the unthinkable: he stole our soul. By adopting the "Native" mask, by refusing to dismantle the corrupt local factions, and by buying off the wavering elites, Lien suffocated the Democratic Progressive Party in its crib. Poor A-Bian! He screamed the truth, but the people were deafened by the KMT's money and blinded by their fake localization.

Look at them now! Ma Ying-jeou, the smiling hypocrite who ruled for eight years (2008-2016). And worst of all, Tsai Ing-wen. A traitor to her blood! A Taiwanese woman leading the Chinese Nationalist Party (2016-2024)! She and her lackey Cheng Li-wun claim to protect our sovereignty, but they do so under the blood-stained flag of the ROC. They have turned our sacred drive for Independence (台獨) into a hollow status quo.

They say the KMT is "indigenized." LIES! A thief who learns the dialect of his victim is still a thief! The "Republic of China" is a shackle, a zombie corpse that Tsai Ing-wen parades around to keep the Americans happy and the voters asleep. They have institutionalized the corruption of the factions and called it "democracy."

The Tangwai spirit is dead. The dream of a Republic of Taiwan (台灣共和國) is dying in the darkness, strangled not by Beijing, but by a KMT that learned how to be Taiwanese better than we did.

TAIWAN IS NOT CHINA! THE ROC IS AN ALIEN REGIME!
JUSTICE FOR A-BIAN! JUSTICE FOR THE PEOPLE!

THE REPORTER | DEEP ANALYSIS

September 19, 2020 • Politics • Taipei

The Eternal Magician: How Lee Teng-hui Lives On Through the Party He Changed

As the "Father of Democracy" is laid to rest, four generations of KMT leadership—Lien, Ma, Soong, and current President Tsai—stand united. They are the living proof that Lee's vision for a "Native KMT" didn't just survive; it conquered.

The rain at the Wuzhi Mountain Military Cemetery fell silently today, washing over a scene that would have been unimaginable to a political observer from the 1990s timeline where the Blue and Green camps split irreconcilably.

In the front row, amidst the political heavyweights, sat Lien Chan (連戰) (2000–2008), Ma Ying-jeou (馬英九) (2008–2016), and the current President, Tsai Ing-wen (蔡英文) (2016–2024). A few rows back, conspicuously rigid, was James Soong (宋楚瑜). Soong, the ultimate standard-bearer for the traditional KMT, stood as a relic of the party Lien successfully dismantled. When Lien Chan chose to fully embrace Lee Teng-hui's "Taiwanized" vision after his 2000 win, Soong's People First Party (PFP) became the repository for the KMT's alienated mainland-leaning and deeply conservative local factions. But without Lien’s decisive break, Soong’s political influence slowly withered, leaving him today as a historical footnote, a man who represented the party that almost was.

The turning point was, of course, the election of 2000. When Lien Chan won that razor-thin victory, he did not purge the "Lee Teng-hui line" as the deep-blue hardliners demanded. Instead, Lien doubled down. He recognized that for the KMT to survive in a democratic Taiwan, it had to become Taiwan. He kept the "Special State-to-State" framework, he promoted the localization wing, and he marginalized the unificationists. The defeated opposition candidate, Chen Shui-bian (陳水扁), watched the ground beneath the DPP's feet disappear as the KMT co-opted the core of the democratic identity movement.

Lien's two terms (2000–2008) cemented the KMT as the "Party of the Status Quo," effectively neutralizing the DPP's narrative. This legacy was passed to Ma Ying-jeou, whose Vice President, the brilliant technocrat Tsai Ing-wen (a former drafter of Lee’s "Two States" theory whom Lien had kept in the National Security Council), provided the ideological bridge. Ma's eight years (2008–2016) were marked by economic pragmatism, but always safeguarded by Tsai's watchful eye on sovereignty.

And now, we are in the era of President Tsai Ing-wen (2016–2024). A KMT member, yet the spiritual granddaughter of Lee Teng-hui. Her Vice President, Cheng Li-wun (鄭麗文), further embodies this successful transformation. Cheng, a former student activist and liberal intellectual who once vehemently opposed the KMT establishment, was successfully recruited and promoted by the reformed party. Her presence on the current KMT ticket symbolizes the party's effective absorption of several generations of young, local, and professional Taiwanese elite. They dominate the center ground, leaving the opposition DPP struggling for air on the radical fringes.

As the bugle played "Taps," Lien Chan was seen wiping a tear. He looked over at President Tsai, who bowed deeply to Lee's portrait. The "Magician" of Taiwanese politics has cast his final spell: he destroyed the old KMT to save it, ensuring that whoever sits in the Presidential Office, it is his philosophy that rules.

Analysis: The "Lee Dynasty" — How the KMT's 24-year continuous rule redefined the Republic of China on Taiwan.

(鄭麗文)		 14 (2016)
20 May 2020 20 May 2024 15 (2020)
`); // 2. 锁定后续动作 exclusive_action_executed = true; // 3. 更改结局背景图片 e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/ROCPE.jpg?v=1764174039638'})]); } // 【最外层条件】只有当候选人ID匹配连战时，才执行后续复杂的决策逻辑 if (aa[0].candidate === LIEN_ID) { // ==================================================================== // A. 高度胜利代码块 (V > 40) // ==================================================================== if (!exclusive_action_executed && V > 40) { // 判定条件：连战(ID 68) 且 得票率 > 40% (意外的大胜) // 语境：原本预估苦战，结果大赢，喜出望外，如释重負 // 情境 1：C 成功 & P 达标 (e.Centralway >= 3, e.PoliticalReformPromise >= 3) if (!exclusive_action_executed&& e.Centralway >= CW_HIGH && e.PoliticalReformPromise >= PRP_HIGH) { // 1. Push the narrative ending e.pages.push(`

The Silver State Traveler: A Postcard from the "Asian Switzerland"

October 15, 2022 – Taipei, Taiwan

The humidity here hits you like a warm, thick blanket, but the energy of the city is electric—yet somehow polite. I’m sitting in a cafe in Ximending, nursing a bubble milk tea that tastes nothing like the watered-down versions back home in Nevada. My phone is blowing up with headlines about the coming U.S. midterms—more mudslinging, more doom. It feels like we are on the brink of another political civil war. But here, everything is quiet, functional, and organized.

I came here expecting the wild, chaotic democracy I read about in old history textbooks concerning the 1990s—the parliamentary brawls, the 'Black Gold' corruption, the constant tension. Honestly, before I booked the trip, I Googled their Presidents. Lien Chan? Never heard of him. Just an old photo of a reserved, serious guy in a suit.

Later, over dinner at Shilin Night Market (where I devoured a truly spectacular stinky tofu and fried chicken cutlet), I asked my local guide, a retired schoolteacher named Mrs. Lin, about that period. I asked, "Who was that Lien Chan guy? Was he corrupt like the others?"

Mrs. Lin smiled, a patient, knowing smile. "No, Mr. Smith. He was the exception. The turning point," she told me. "He was the one who broke it. He won that chaotic election in 2000 with ${FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT.toFixed(1)}% of the vote, but he had campaigned on a platform of Central Way and Institutional Reform."

She explained how Lien served two terms, not just growing the economy, but using his mandate to dismantle the old patronage networks. He didn't just talk about reform; he implemented transparent laws and established independent anti-corruption bodies. He purged the political system of the toxins left by the previous era. He successfully gave the KMT a new, clean soul.

The result is a political continuity that is staggering for a democracy. Lien handed over a prosperous, stable, high-tech economy to Ma Ying-jeou in 2008. Ma stabilized cross-strait relations without sacrificing dignity. And then, in 2016, the torch was passed to the current President, Tsai Ing-wen—a brilliant technocrat and a proud member of the modern KMT. This is a country where power transitions are seamless, institutional, and based on merit, not emotion.

The best part? It filters down to the local level. There are local mayoral elections happening right now. Yesterday, I watched a mayoral candidate—a young, sharp-looking woman—campaigning in Tamsui Old Street. An elderly man tried to hand her a large red envelope—a traditional gesture of favor. In the old days, she would have taken it as part of the "soft" network. But she didn't. She gently pushed it back, pointed to her campaign badge, and bowed deeply. "Service, not favors," my guide translated. The crowd nodded in silent approval.

There is no vote-buying. No mass bribery. The voters here demand policy debates, clear legislative agendas, and clean finance. They demand rational choices, not sensationalism. It makes me deeply sad to admit this, but as an American watching our own polarized mess, our endless culture wars, and the sheer desperation of our politics back home, I have to conclude: Taiwan's political maturity has surpassed the United States.

Lien Chan promised a "New Middle Way" twenty-two years ago. Looking at this prosperous, calm, and dignified island—from the bustling night markets to the respectful political rallies—I’d say he delivered on the creation of a truly civilized society.

The Gallery of Shadows: Presidential Office, 2028

May 19, 2028 – The Night Before the Inauguration

Rain lashes against the bulletproof glass of the Presidential Office. Inside, the hallways are silent. Chiang Wan-an, the President-elect and Chairman of the Kuomintang, walks slowly down the corridor lined with the portraits of his predecessors. He stops before each one, feeling the weight of the party's century-long burden.

He pauses at the portrait of his great-grandfather, the Generalissimo, Chiang Kai-shek (蔣中正). The figure who centralized the splintered nation. He reflects on the immense task of the Northern Expedition (北伐), where the KMT unified a war-torn China under one flag after decades of warlordism. Even more monumental was his role in the Eight Years' War of Resistance against Japan (抗日戰爭). The Generalissimo led China through unimaginable sacrifice to victory against a brutal imperial power, securing China's place as one of the major Allied powers. Yet, he also brought the party to this island, established the foundation of security, and the strict, centralized discipline of the state—a legacy of strong central control and authoritarian habits that still haunts every KMT chairman.

He glances quickly at Yen Chia-kan, the technocrat who quietly managed the transition of power and the shock of Taiwan's withdrawal from the UN—a necessary, often overlooked bridge.

Next is his grandfather, Chiang Ching-kuo (蔣經國). A complex figure who built the economic miracle and, in the final years of his life, made the difficult choice to unleash democracy. He ended martial law, legalized new parties, and set the KMT on the path of localization. He opened the door, knowing the party might fall, for the sake of the country.

He moves past Lee Teng-hui, the man who completed the democratization but whose strategy of consolidating power fractured the KMT and ushered in the era of "Black Gold"—a necessary evil, some argued, to secure the party's survival in a democratic age. A poison pill.

Then, Chiang Wan-an stops for a long time in front of the portrait of Lien Chan (連戰).

History records Lien Chan as the savior of the KMT in 2000. He defeated Chen Shui-bian and James Soong with ${FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT.toFixed(1)}% of the vote, securing the "Central Way" and preventing the island's dangerous drift toward conflict. He was a good steward who kept the economy growing and the peace secured.

"But you compromised, didn't you, Uncle Lien?" Chiang whispers to the painted canvas.

Lien Chan's hard-won victory in 2000 was bought with a trade-off. To ensure victory, he had to rely on the local factions, the agricultural associations, and the patronage networks that defined the Lee Teng-hui era. He chose stability over radical surgery. The "Black Gold" wasn't removed; it was simply contained, managed, and hidden under a veneer of prosperity and stability. He kept the KMT in power, but he failed to truly redeem its soul.

Chiang moves on to Ma Ying-jeou, who succeeded Lien in 2008. Ma tried to be the reformer Lien wasn't, but the roots of the factions were too deep by then, leading to his eventual stagnation. Then came Eric Chu, who managed the party's stagnation against a rising populist tide.

Now, it is 2028. The KMT still holds power, but it is a tired giant. The younger generation views the party not with hatred, but with indifference—seeing it as a machine of "connections" and entrenched interests. The persistent issues of high housing prices and wage stagnation are constant threats. The shadow of factional politics still looms over every local election.

Chiang Wan-an sighs, adjusting his tie. If Lien Chan had used his mandate in 2000 to be ruthless—to truly cage the Black Gold, to embrace the difficult pain of systemic reform instead of the comfort of maintaining tradition—how much stronger, cleaner, and more vital would Taiwan be today? The KMT survived, yes. But looking at the tired face of the party he now leads, Chiang wonders if survival was the best they could have hoped for.

`); // 2. Push the narrative ending e.pages.push(`

The History Teacher's Lament: A Classroom in Taipei, 2021

Posted: November 10, 2021 – History Department Office, Taipei Middle School

Today, in my ninth-grade history class, the silence was chilling. I was lecturing on the Song Dynasty and intended to reference the patriotic devotion of figures like Yue Fei and Wen Tianxiang to illustrate historical duty and responsibility. I asked the students who Wen Tianxiang was, but instead of answers, I got hesitant looks. A student politely raised their hand to ask: "Teacher, who is Wen Tianxiang? Is he a historical figure from a city in Taiwan? I only know about Koxinga and Lin Hsien-tang, or perhaps the figures from the Indigenous cultures..."

The moment hit me hard. This is not an isolated incident. The process of de-Sinicization has been quiet but relentless, infiltrating our curricula and subtly shaping the worldview of an entire generation. Their primary frame of reference is now entirely local. The shared emotional anchor to the mainland's past—the poetry, the loyalty, the grand sweep of Chinese history—is simply unfamiliar, like an old language no longer spoken.

The institutional foundations of our governance are solid. Taiwan is widely recognized as one of Asia's least corrupt regions. That achievement is the direct result of the 2000 election; President Lien Chan (連戰) won with a thin margin of ${FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT.toFixed(1)}% and immediately enacted ruthless anti-corruption laws and institutional reforms, ending the "Black Gold" era for good. This stability is why KMT mayors, like Simon Chang (張善政), can focus entirely on infrastructure and technocratic governance, proudly touting "clean governance" dividends.

However, that political success came with a cost. Lien Chan’s victory was achieved by compromising on the "Central Way" and conceding cultural influence to localist pressure. Even under continuous KMT rule, the cultural and educational policies adopted since 2000 have been based on a policy of "non-interference." The result is that while we have political stability, we have cultural drift.

The latest public opinion surveys from the Mainland Affairs Council confirm the shift: the percentage of people identifying solely as "Chinese" has dropped to a historical low. The vast majority now identify as "Taiwanese," or at best, "both." The KMT delivered clean government and economic stability, but it utterly failed to preserve a shared cultural identity or sense of historical belonging. The political ground beneath us is shifting.

With the 2024 Presidential Election fast approaching, this shift in the identity bedrock of the Taiwanese electorate could be decisive. Regardless of the KMT's spotless governance record, the fundamental question of "Who are we?"—a question the KMT deliberately avoided for decades—may now deliver a structural advantage to the DPP. We fixed the money, but we are losing the hearts of the next generation.

– Recorded on an unsettling autumn afternoon.

`); // 2. Author  NostalgiaTW  (NostalgicTaiwan)      Board  Gossiping
Title  [GOSSIP] Dug up 20-year-old antiques! Anyone remember voting for Lien-Siew?
Time  Wed Jul 15 23:30:12 2020
───────────────────────────────────────

Hello everyone! Just moved house and while tidying, I found a dusty old box, and seeing this made me almost cry!

This is the Lien-Siew campaign merchandise I got from a rally during the 2000 Presidential Election! A silver jacket with the blue and orange butterfly logo and the shape of Taiwan. It was super popular back then!

I had just gotten voting rights that year, and I voted mostly out of simple excitement and following the crowd. Even though President Lien Chan’s strategy (neither the middle way nor the reform promises) seemed particularly clear, he still won with a surprisingly high ${FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT.toFixed(1)}% of the vote, and was re-elected successfully until 2008. Looking back, it truly was a miracle; maybe too many external factors intervened?

Seeing these items makes me nostalgic for that simpler time. Did anyone else vote for Lien-Siew back then? Doesn't time fly?

-- ※ Origin: Ptt BBS System (ptt.cc), From: Taiwan
-- ※ Article URL: https://www.ptt.cc/Gossiping/M.609439281.A.41A.html

A stable but bland period. Hopefully President Han Kuo-yu can bring some real change, but the blue-green rivalry is still exhausting.
噓 IndependenceNOW: The KMT is stuck in the past. Lien Chan won by pure luck and wasted his chance. He just kicked the can down the road. Why are we talking about 2000 when we should be talking about the future of a sovereign nation?
推 DeepBlueTaiwan: All you greens get lost! KMT's base is bigger, deal with it! President Han Kuo-yu is the will of the people!

20 May 2020 20 May 2024 15 (2020)
16 Lai Ching-te 賴清德 (Born 1959) 20 May 2024 Incumbent Democratic Progressive Party Hsiao Bi-khim 16 (2024)
`); // 2. 锁定后续动作 exclusive_action_executed = true; // 3. 更改结局背景图片 e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/ROCPE.jpg?v=1764174039638'})]); } } // ==================================================================== // B. 中度胜利代码块 (35 < V <= 40) // ==================================================================== if (!exclusive_action_executed && V > 35 && V <= 40) { // 判定条件：连战(ID 68) 且 得票率在 35% - 40% 之间 (惊险胜出，依靠萧万长稳住本土票) // 情境 5：C 成功 & P 达标 (e.Centralway >= 3, e.PoliticalReformPromise >= 3) if (!exclusive_action_executed&& e.Centralway >= CW_HIGH && e.PoliticalReformPromise >= PRP_HIGH) { // 1. Push the narrative ending e.pages.push(`

January 15, 2024 – An Eternal Opposition

The Unseen Victory of the Center

By Chen Yi-hsiung (Taipei, Private Blog Entry)

The rain feels colder tonight. It always does on January 15th. The confetti from the KMT victory rally has already washed into the gutters. This time, the winner is Cheng Li-wun (鄭麗文), the newest face of the perennial ruling party. We, the few left who still believe in the green flag, are left to clean up the signs and count the ballots—another election lost, another eight years guaranteed for the Blue Machine.

We saw this day coming, didn't we? The moment wasn't 2004, or 2008, or even 2016. The moment was 2000. That election, where everyone in our camp believed the KMT's internal corruption and fracture would deliver us victory on a silver platter.

Instead, Lien Chan emerged with ${FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT.toFixed(1)}% of the vote. We laughed at the low percentage, but we missed the point. He didn't just win; he executed a political maneuver that rewired the entire system. By championing both a pragmatic "Central Way"—keeping the economy humming and cross-strait policy stable—and, critically, by following through with genuine political reform, he did the unthinkable: he stabilized the post-Lee Teng-hui KMT.

Lien Chan's eight years established the precedent. Ma Ying-jeou's eight years expanded the economy. When the time came for a change, the KMT didn't fall; it merely rotated its leader. We watched as Tsai Ing-wen—yes, that Tsai Ing-wen—ascended to the presidency under the blue banner from 2016 to 2024. The KMT had cannily absorbed the 'nativist' current, leaving our party stranded.

Our DPP, unable to secure the pragmatic middle ground, retreated deeper into a principled but electorally marginal stance of radical independence. In a country that prizes stability and clean administration, our core message is now perceived as destabilizing and unnecessary. We are trapped, destined to serve as the perpetual conscience, the noisy opposition that reminds the KMT to stay clean, but is never allowed to hold the reins.

Sometimes, I look to the People First Party (PFP), the loyal opposition that broke away two decades ago. James Soong (宋楚瑜), bless his tenacity, ran tirelessly against the KMT, hoping to prove they were the true alternative. But the PFP, having never won the ultimate prize, is now an irrelevant echo, losing its purpose since Soong’s retirement. They tried to be the centrist check, but the KMT simply stole the center.

Twenty-four years. Lien Chan’s success wasn't just a political victory; it was a structural triumph, a quiet, lasting institutionalization of a modernized KMT dominance. We are not watching a democracy in crisis; we are watching a highly effective, one-party-dominant system at work. And I feel the weight of every single one of those years crushing our hopes for a real change.

The Asia-Pacific Observer | Taiwan Analysis

The Sins of the Father? Taipei's Mayoral Race Becomes a Referendum on the Lien Dynasty

By David K. Richards | November 22, 2014

TAIPEI — By all conventional political wisdom, Sean Lien (連勝文) should be measuring the drapes in Taipei City Hall right now. As the son of former President Lien Chan (2000–2008) and the anointed candidate of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) under current President Ma Ying-jeou, he is running in a deep-blue stronghold that hasn't elected a non-KMT mayor in nearly two decades.

Yet, the mood inside Lien's campaign headquarters is reportedly one of "panic and paralysis." Internal polls show him trailing the independent candidate, a blunt trauma surgeon named Ko Wen-je (柯文哲), by double digits.

Why is the princeling flailing? The answer lies buried in the legacy of his father's presidency.

When Lien Chan won the presidency in 2000 with ${FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT.toFixed(1)}% of the vote, he did so by stabilizing cross-strait relations and consolidating the KMT's traditional organizational machine. However, critics argue that his victory came at a price: the abandonment of internal political reform. To secure his fragile mandate, President Lien chose not to dismantle the KMT's vast and controversial party assets or the local patronage networks known as "Black Gold." Instead, he managed them.

Fourteen years later, that decision has come back to haunt his son.

Ko Wen-je and his unofficial allies in the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) have ruthlessly weaponized the Lien family's wealth. "Where did the money come from?" has become the defining question of the 2014 race. Campaign ads juxtapose the struggles of Taipei's youth with the lavish lifestyle of the Lien family, directly linking their fortune to the "privileges" preserved during Lien Chan's eight-year term.

"President Lien Chan had eight years to clear his name and reform the party assets," says Prof. Lin Chang-zuo, a political analyst at National Taiwan University. "He didn't. He chose stability over surgery. Now, Sean Lien is carrying the baggage of that unresolved history. The voters see him not as a fresh face, but as the heir to a system of privilege that was never dismantled."

The attacks are sticking. The "White Force" phenomenon led by Ko is sweeping through the capital, painting the Lien dynasty as the embodiment of a corrupt, untouchable elite. The KMT's traditional "iron votes" are rusting away, disillusioned by the stagnation of the Ma Ying-jeou era and the perceived arrogance of the Lien clan.

In 2000, Lien Chan saved the KMT by preserving the status quo. In 2014, it appears that very same status quo might finally cost his family—and his party—their crown jewel: the capital city of Taipei.

THE GEOPOLITICAL MONITOR | EAST ASIA DESK

Triangle of Fire: Taiwan's KMT Throws Gasoline on the Diaoyu Islands Dispute

By Simon H. Sterling | September 25, 2012

TOKYO/TAIPEI — The standoff in the East China Sea took a sharp and dangerous turn this morning, not from a move by Tokyo or Beijing, but from an unexpectedly defiant statement out of Taipei. As Chinese naval vessels circle the disputed Diaoyu (Senkaku) Islands, the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou has shattered any hope of a unified "One China" front against Japan.

In a press conference that has sent shockwaves through the Politburo in Beijing, the Republic of China (Taiwan) Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesperson issued a statement that was less a claim of sovereignty and more a declaration of distinct identity:

"The Diaoyu Islands are the inherent territory of the Republic of China, administered by Yilan County. We must clarify to the international community: The Diaoyu Islands belong to the Republic of China, and the authorities in Beijing have never exercised rule over Taiwan, nor have they ever ruled the Diaoyu Islands. Our sovereignty is distinct, historical, and undeniable."

The reaction from Beijing was immediate and furious. The Taiwan Affairs Office has condemned the statement as "separatism disguised as patriotism" and suspended the already limited low-level trade talks scheduled for next month. Cross-strait relations, which never truly warmed beyond the small scale of the Mini Three Links (金馬三通), have effectively frozen.

To understand why the KMT is prioritizing this confrontation, one must look back to the election of 2000. When Lien Chan won that pivotal race with ${FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT.toFixed(1)}% of the vote, he secured power by abandoning the "Central Way" of cross-strait rapprochement in favor of the "Taiwanization" strategy of his predecessor, Lee Teng-hui. Lien’s eight-year presidency (2000–2008) solidified a structure within the party: high internal reform, but deep suspicion of Beijing.

President Ma Ying-jeou, who succeeded Lien in 2008, inherited this political climate. Ma, with his mainland family background, is constantly struggling to avoid being labeled "pro-China" by a newly invigorated localist wing within his own party and the opposition. This internal pressure forces his administration to adopt aggressively distinct foreign policy positions—even on an issue like the Diaoyu Islands, where a unified Chinese stance might seem strategically advantageous. This KMT must always prove its "Taiwan First" bona fides to its electorate.

Today's statement confirms Beijing's worst fear: the KMT has not returned to the fold; it has become a competitor that claims the legacy of China while firmly rejecting the jurisdiction of the PRC. The political landscape is no longer blue vs. green; it is Taiwan (represented by a 'Native Blue' KMT) vs. Beijing.

As Japanese Coast Guard ships spray water cannons at Taiwanese fishing boats and PLAAF fighters scramble from Fujian, the East China Sea has become a three-way deadlock, with Taipei standing defiantly alone.

Push the narrative ending e.pages.push(`

September 2023 — The Study, Cathay A-Grade Mansion

The Bronze Seal and the Vanishing Kingdom

Outside, the rain pounds against the thick windows of the Cathay A-Grade Mansion, the sound dull and distant, much like history's final verdict on an era. I watch Lai Ching-te's face on the television; he is calm, confident, discussing his re-election bid and the "New Taiwan Vision." He represents the future we could have strangled in its cradle, but instead allowed to flourish. I pick up the heavy jade paperweight on my desk, my fingers tracing the cold, irrevocable weight of it.

The year 2000. I won, squeezing through with a narrow ${FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT.toFixed(1)}% of the vote. That victory was not a flame, but an ember. It brought no rebirth, only eight years of precarious survival. People called my presidency the "Tranquility at the Turn of the Century," but beneath the tranquility was fear—fear of the knife. We inherited the shell of localization from the Lee Teng-hui era, but lacked the courage to touch the rot underneath the surface.

We failed to implement any meaningful systemic reforms. The vast party assets, the local Black Gold factions, the old bureaucratic structures—they secured my victory, but they also became the noose around the KMT's neck. For the sake of immediate political stability, I avoided the difficult task of charting a strong "Central Way." Cross-strait engagement stalled at a symbolic level, and the internal surgery I most needed to perform was delayed again and again.

But hindsight is always easy. Did the situation at the time truly permit me to proceed with an axe?

“The KMT was already fractured in four directions, and our vote share was barely above 35%. If I had pushed for comprehensive reform then, it would have immediately triggered internal collapse, perhaps repeating the instability of the late President Lee's years. My choice of Wang Jin-pyng (王金平) as my successor was also a necessity—to unite the local factions and safeguard the KMT's core foundation. He was the only one who could stabilize the situation at that moment, and he bought us four years... four years should have been enough.”

The irony is inescapable: the wealth and comfort of this mansion are precisely why the KMT needed radical treatment, and why we always hesitated to deliver it. We were too afraid of losing what we had, so we ultimately lost everything.

Wang Jin-pyng’s defeat was the final fall of the KMT’s fate. Su Tseng-chang’s (蘇貞昌) victory in 2012 marked the first irreversible shift in Taiwan's political structure. Su won re-election in 2016. In 2020, our desperate attempt to counter the green wave with the populist outsider Han Kuo-yu (韓國瑜) failed, accelerating our decline and handing the presidency to Lai Ching-te.

Now, Eric Chu (朱立倫) shoulders the nearly impossible burden of challenging the DPP’s established rule in 2024. We spent eight years on the throne without laying a single foundation for the next two decades. I won the election of 2000, but I lost the KMT's future. During that seemingly stable presidency, I chose to **appease** rather than **cure**, and history accepts no excuses. In this most solid tower in Taipei, I hear not the echo of glory, but the silence of a dynasty's collapse. That victory was nothing more than a thin golden veneer over our ultimate failure.

`); // 2. 锁定后续动作 exclusive_action_executed = true; // 3. 更改结局背景图片 e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/ROCPE.jpg?v=1764174039638'})]); } // 情境 8b：C 因素在最低地带 (0 <= C < 3) 且 P 不足 if( !exclusive_action_executed&& V > 35 && V <= 40) { // This is the fallback ending where Lien Chan won in 2000, but his presidency (2000-2004) was inert // and led to a highly unified opposition that defeated him in 2004. // 1. Push the narrative ending e.pages.push(`

March 2004 — Lugang, Changhua County

The Price of Peanuts: The Folly of the Old KMT

It was March 16th. The campaign worker, a young man sweating in a blue windbreaker, spoke the KMT's mantra with weary conviction: "Stability! Continuity! Vote Lien-Siew!" He bowed deeply, placing the small, discreet package into the hands of Grandpa Lin, who sat on his porch nursing a cup of tea. It was two days before the election.

Inside the package, wrapped in red paper, was the offering: two bags of high-grade Lugang peanut brittle, a Lien-Siew rally towel, and a thick, crisp envelope containing NT$2,000. It wasn't exactly bribery; it was "transportation compensation."

Grandpa Lin’s six-year-old grandson, A-Hao, immediately snatched the peanut brittle. "Grandpa, why is the KMT always giving us food and money?"

Lin smiled, his face a roadmap of Taiwan's political history. "Because, A-Hao, President Lien Chan (連戰) won the last election in 2000 with ${FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT.toFixed(1)}% of the vote by promising nothing much and changing even less. He was President Lee's slow sequel. Now he needs these little gifts to remind people why they should keep the rusty old machine running. That's the KMT way."

Lien Chan's four years had been marked by remarkable inertia. There was no decisive move on cross-strait relations, nor any significant political housecleaning. He simply occupied the presidential office, assuming the loyalty of the party and the electorate was an eternal, inherited asset.

But 2004 was different. The opposition wasn't fractured this time. The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), having bitterly realized their failures in 1996 and 2000 were primarily due to the anti-KMT vote being split, swallowed their ideological pride. In a desperate, historic maneuver, they threw their full support behind James Soong (宋楚瑜) and his running mate, the veteran independence advocate Lu Hsiu-lien (呂秀蓮). The "Green-Red Alliance," as some called it, was formed with one singular goal: Anyone but Lien.

As Lin counted the money, he thought of the radio speeches he’d heard. Soong spoke of cleaning up the 'Black Gold' and forcing the KMT to reform—the exact things Lien Chan had refused to do. The opposition’s message was unified, focusing their attacks not on ideology, but on the KMT's arrogance and stasis.

“Did we have to change anything?” Lin mused, watching A-Hao chew the brittle. “They think a bit of money and a comfortable life is enough to win our loyalty forever.”

The election day, March 18th, arrives. Lin, carrying his ID card, walks to the polling station. He remembers the peanuts, the towel, and the crisp NT$2,000. He smiles, a slow, deep chuckle reserved for irony. The KMT had given him a gift, a perfect metaphor for the stale, stagnant power they offered.

He enters the booth. He glances at the KMT's square, red stamp. Then, with a practiced firmness, he places his vote on the name of James Soong and the Grand Opposition Ticket.

The results that night are devastating for the Blue camp. The Soong-Lu coalition wins with a definitive 50.2% of the vote, narrowly securing the presidency against Lien Chan’s 49.8%. Despite the clear margin, the KMT, reeling from the shock of losing power, immediately mobilizes their legal teams to challenge the razor-thin defeat, claiming irregularities in what they deem an unprecedented betrayal of the political establishment. The island faces days, if not weeks, of legal and political turmoil. As Grandpa Lin watches the PFP victory fireworks on TV, he whispers to his grandson, "The KMT thinks the people are for sale, A-Hao. But sometimes, they just buy their own rope."

`); // 2. Execute the image change e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/changhua.jpg?v=1765904184274'})]); // 3. [Historic] 2021 National Day Ceremony: Three former Presidents—Lien, Soong, and Ma—all in attendance to watch President Lai Ching-te's address. What a timeline.

Seeing Lien Chan there is bittersweet. People forget he won in 2000 with less than 35% of the vote, yet he pushed through the brutal party reform anyway. He knew the local factions (那些牛鬼蛇神) would bolt to Soong, but he chose to save the KMT's future over his own re-election. If he hadn't cleaned house, Ma wouldn't have had a party worth taking over in 2012. He traded four years for the KMT's two decades. Respect.

Push the narrative (Political Analysis Article Style - Fully English, with Su Tseng-chang as the 2016 DPP nominee) e.pages.push(`
THE FORMOSA REVIEW
Independent Analysis • Since 1998
November 8, 2015

The Singapore Gamble: Why Ma is Replaying Lien Chan's 2005 Playbook, and Why it Will Fail

With the KMT explicitly fracturing and polling numbers in freefall, the President looks to the mainland for a miracle. The election is already decided, but Ma seeks redemption.

By Lin Yu-Hsiang | Senior Political Correspondent

The 80-second handshake between President Ma Ying-jeou and Xi Jinping (*the first meeting between the leaders of Taiwan and mainland China since 1949*) at the Shangri-La Hotel yesterday was designed to be a thunderclap that would instantly rewrite the 2016 election narrative. However, in Taipei, the event feels more like a distant, desperate echo of a fading political era. To understand the political calculus behind Ma Ying-jeou's decision to meet Xi, we must look back to the playbook written by his predecessor, Lien Chan.

I. The Ghost of 2005: A Strategy Born of Weakness

History repeats itself, first as tragedy, then as farce. In 2005, President Lien Chan was in a precarious position. Having scraped through re-election in 2004 with a razor-thin margin and facing a legitimacy crisis, he needed to silence the rising threat of James Soong’s PFP and consolidate the Pan-Blue base. His answer was the historic "Ice-Breaking Journey" to Beijing.

It was a spectacle of high drama—who can forget the surreal scene at the Xi'an primary school, with children chanting "Grandpa Lien, you have returned!" (yéye nín huíláile)? Lien successfully achieved his short-term goal: he marginalized Soong and paved the way for Ma’s eventual dominance starting in 2008. The context was consolidation of a winning coalition.

II. The 2015 Scenario: Desperation, Not Consolidation

Ma Ying-jeou’s situation in 2015 is far more dire. His administration is crippled by the scandals of the Ma-Wang political feud and the massive public backlash of the 2014 Sunflower Movement. Most recently, the party inflicted the self-wound of the candidate change (*known colloquially as 'pillar replacement,' where the KMT removed its initial presidential nominee, Hung Hsiu-chu, in favor of Eric Chu*). The party is not just divided; it is bleeding support, especially among young, educated urban voters who have rejected the KMT's core economic policies.

Ma’s gambit in Singapore is not about consolidation; it is a desperate attempt to save his historical legacy and provide an artificial jolt to Eric Chu's flailing campaign. By forcing this meeting, Ma hopes to recreate the "War and Peace" choice that benefited the KMT in the 2000s, positioning the KMT as the only party capable of maintaining cross-strait stability.

III. The Electoral Landscape: A Fundamental Shift

The critical difference lies in the public mood. In 2005, many Taiwanese still viewed engagement with Beijing as a pathway to economic prosperity and regional stability. Today, the skepticism is profound:

  • Youth Activism: The Sunflower generation now treats the "China card" not as an economic lifeline, but as a threat to sovereignty and democracy. They reject the notion that cross-strait stability justifies poor governance at home.
  • Economic Fatigue: The average Taiwanese citizen has not felt the benefits of Ma's cross-strait policy. The promised trickle-down effect from major economic agreements has failed to materialize, leading to palpable anxiety over stagnant wages and rising inequality.
  • Timing and Trust: Unlike Lien’s visit which occurred between elections, Ma’s meeting is overtly political and poorly timed. After the self-sabotage of the candidate change, the public trust in the KMT’s ability to govern and select credible leaders is at an all-time low.

Current polling figures (post-candidate change and pre-Ma-Xi meeting) already show Eric Chu trailing DPP candidate Su Tseng-chang by an insurmountable margin—often 15 to 20 percentage points. The hope that the Ma-Xi meeting could dramatically shift a double-digit deficit is fantasy. At best, it might slightly boost the KMT’s legislative ticket or marginally increase deep-blue turnout, but the presidential race appears irrevocably lost.

The irony of the Singapore meeting is stark. Lien Chan went to China to save a winning but fragile coalition. Ma Ying-jeou goes to Singapore to save his historical positioning, but in doing so, he is underscoring the KMT's fundamental disconnect with a rapidly changing electorate. The thunderclap Ma sought merely illuminates the cracks in the KMT's old foundation.

Observation: KMT Polling figures for Eric Chu remain stagnant at roughly 20-25%, trailing DPP's Su Tseng-chang by double digits. The "Ma-Xi Bump" has not materialized in early phone surveys. The party's decision to prioritize cross-strait optics over addressing domestic economic anxiety is fueling voter cynicism, particularly in the critical 20-40 age demographic.

Push the narrative (Personal Blog Style - Fully English, Seamless Flow, Anchored to Lee Teng-hui, NO BOLDING IN TEXT) e.pages.push(`

@ObserverFrom90s' Musings | December 20, 2019

Our Twenty Years of Politics: A 90s Kid's Life Footnote

From Grandpa Lien’s reform fire to President Gou’s commercial iron fist, how have four presidents shaped our generation?

The election is fast approaching, and the air is thick with tension. I laugh a little seeing President Gou (Terry Gou) on TV shouting, "Give me four years, I'll give you happiness." Seriously, what can four years actually do? Our generation (I was born in '92) has lived through four presidents. For me, politics isn't just names in a history book; it's about typhoons and days off, my salary after graduation, and whether I can afford to buy a small apartment.

I was too young to really remember the Lee Teng-hui era. My childhood memories of him are mostly black-and-white images on the news. The first time I truly felt the pulse of the country, the real excitement and chaos of democracy, was the 2000 Presidential Election. That year, Lien Chan won the office with a disturbingly low vote share—a result of refusing to undertake popular political reforms earlier. My knowledge of politics then was just the constant arguing from my dad's radio. Grandpa Lien was the most anxious man in the KMT; he won the office but lost the party's cohesion. He was desperate to push "sweeping reforms," but this thoroughly alienated the local factions, who defected. He was like an old headmaster rushing to prove himself, only to be consumed by four years of chaos. I graduated elementary school in 2004, the year Grandpa Lien was overturned by the DPP's Chen Shui-bian, marking Taiwan's first political transition.

Chen Shui-bian's (A-Bian) four-year term was when I was in junior high. It was a time of high energy and "inspirational legend"! After two earlier failures in '98 and '00, a political underdog finally realized his dream in 2004. The social mood was electric, everything felt possible and new. My mom, who never talked politics, started watching political talk shows. But the fever cooled quickly. Adults around me began complaining about "corruption," saying he was worse than the old KMT. That four years felt like a speeding roller coaster, full of passion and crushing disappointment. Until 2008, the year I graduated high school, that political fever was finally broken by the PFP's James Soong.

James Soong (Lao Soong) governed for eight full years (2008-2016), covering my college years and my first job. Lao Soong preached "pragmatism" and "setting things right." He lacked Grandpa Lien's radicalism and A-Bian’s fiery passion. His term was eight years of stability—almost boring stability. He focused on governance, and the economy grew steadily, but slowly. Housing prices were stable, and salaries were stable (stuck at a low level). He was like a dutiful civil servant. For us 90s kids, Soong was the safe, uninspiring background music of our adolescence. He ensured we graduated and found secure jobs, but offered no impulse for greater dreams.

Then came Terry Gou. In 2016, the KMT, tired of being sidelined under Soong’s PFP rule, chose to nominate the business magnate. He was not a politician; he was a businessman who shouted, "Taiwanese must make money! Politics, get out of the way!" The public was tired of Soong's safe stability, and the DPP's Su Tseng-chang seemed too conservative. Gou won miraculously in a three-way race, defeating both Su Tseng-chang and the PFP’s Hsieh Kuo-liang. My career and my marriage happened during his term. He made the economic data look great, but he governed with an "overbearing CEO" style that intensified social friction. I wanted to buy a small apartment after getting married, but the housing market surged so fast due to his economic push that it became unaffordable. I realized that a good economy had nothing to do with my personal life. His four years showed me that a CEO-President cannot fix Taiwan.

It's late 2019. President Gou is seeking re-election, challenged by the steady hand of the DPP’s Cheng Wen-tsan and the PFP’s localist Fu Kun-chi. Looking back, Grandpa Lien was the failed pioneer of reform, A-Bian was the embodiment of passion and corruption, Lao Soong was the stable mediocrity, and Terry Gou is the businessman who turned everything into a deal. Our generation grew up in the noise of political transitions, only to be left with a sense of political impotence. I hope the next president truly sees us—not just the cold economic numbers—but our humble desire to have a home and a future. That is the only "political reform" we 90s kids are looking for on the ballot.

Push the narrative (PTT Forum Style - Full English, Black Background, Gossiping Board, NO BOLDING IN TEXT) e.pages.push(`
Author oldKMTfading (Blue Sky Fading) Board Gossiping
Title [Question] What exactly did Lien Chan do during his four years from 2000-2004? Who remembers?
Time Tue Dec 17 00:39:05 2019

Hey everyone, I'm just an otaku reviewing Taiwan's political history lately.

Now, Tsai Ing-wen (Xiao Ying) is running for re-election, and we're used to the DPP being in power. But if you think back, the first party rotation only happened in 2012! James Soong (Lao Soong) served all the way from '04 to '12—eight full years, huge presence.

But I'm curious about the even earlier KMT era, specifically the four years of Lien Chan (2000-2004). What exactly went on?

I was in elementary school back then, and honestly, the biggest feeling was boredom. Television news was always talking about irrelevant international matters, and even though the Legislative Yuan was noisy, it felt like nothing ever came out of the arguments. Prices back then were very stable; a chicken leg bento seemed stuck at around 60 NTD, and housing prices weren't as insane as they are now.

During Lien Chan's four years, the KMT seemed to enter "sleep mode," continuing to operate on the inertia of the late Lee Teng-hui era. No passion, no major reforms, just that kind of "getting by" mediocrity. Lee Teng-hui's political legacy just dragged on blandly for another four years, until it was overturned by Old Soong.

James Soong defeated Lien Chan in 2004 and started his eight years in power (2004-2012). Lao Soong really seemed to be getting things done; he pushed for "efficiency and clean governance." People often said back then, "Mayor Soong is back." Those eight years were marked by a sense of "small pleasures" (Xiao Que Xing) when we were in college. The economy grew slowly but steadily, and while prices were creeping up, the increase was acceptable.

Lao Soong kept politics pragmatic and avoided ideological fights, making it hard for the DPP opposition to find major points of attack in the legislature. The DPP spent those eight years quietly building up their local talent, only seizing the opportunity in 2012 when Lao Soong made a critical mistake, finally achieving the first party rotation under Tsai Ing-wen.

So, Lien Chan’s four years, rather than being KMT governance, felt like "the ghost of Lee Teng-hui’s politics lingering on." His four years of passive mediocrity caused the KMT to lose power in 2004, directly enabling Soong to govern stably for eight years. Were those four years truly the most void and unmemorable period in KMT history?

Does anyone remember any major policies Lien Chan enacted during those four years? Besides his Vice President occasionally saying some utterly boring things, I genuinely can't recall anything significant.

Need the hot gossip!

Push DPPgogogo: Four years of super low presence, only remember Soong winning easily in '04
Push TaipeiGuy: Lien Chan? He was president? I only remember Soong's eight years
Boo BlueSkyAgain: Green army shill above? Lien Chan was the democratic successor to Lee Teng-hui!
Push LittlePotato: I was in elementary school then, only remember the news being boring. Yeah, 60 NTD bento seems right.
Push FormosaDream: Lien Chan's four years was the KMT playing asleep, waiting for Soong to slap them awake
Boo KMTisBEST: Chairman Lien is such a good person! He even held me when I was a baby! You 90s haters wouldn't understand
Push SalaryStuck: Lao Soong's eight years were dull, but at least stable, unlike Xiao Ying's constant fighting these past few years
Boo RealPolitik: Lien Chan was a transitional figure, he completed Lee Teng-hui's final mission, you're asking too much
Push LunchBoxLife: Inflation was super stable those years, unlike now where everything is expensive
Push oldKMTfading: Thanks for the memories... It really was four years of blank space, followed by Soong's eight years of small pleasures...
Boo NoGreenNoTalk: Trash post! Lien Chan's character is far superior to anyone on the political stage now!
-- ※ Origin: PTT Bulletin Board (ptt.cc), From: 118.165.188.100 (Taiwan)
`); // 2. Push the narrative (TVBS News Report Style - Full English, Chen Shui-bian is President, No Subheadings/Bolding) e.pages.push(`

TVBS News Report

Published: 2011/XX/XX Evening News Exclusive

Lee Teng-hui's 90th Birthday Century Mystery! A-Bian and Lao Soong Mingle, Ma and Wang Present, Why Did Lien Chan Refuse to Attend?

Taiwan's deepest political feud! Three former heads of state, one no-show: The love-hate drama of 2004 lingers on.

Former President Lee Teng-hui hosted a grand 90th birthday banquet today. This 'Century Banquet' was not just a celebration, but a political drama filled with undercurrents, dubbed a "Grand Reconciliation Show of Taiwan's Political Feuds"! The venue was packed with political heavyweights: Incumbent President Chen Shui-bian (A-Bian), former Provincial Governor James Soong (Lao Soong), former Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, and Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng all attended, causing a constant flurry of camera flashes.

The most unexpected highlight was the cordial interaction between President Chen Shui-bian and former Governor James Soong near the main table. The two men were seen chatting and smiling, making the fierce rivalry of yesteryear seem to vanish. In a highly symbolic moment, James Soong raised his glass to Mr. Lee, stating: "Without your cultivation, Mr. Lee Teng-hui, there would be no James Soong, the Governor of Taiwan Province." This emotional gesture suggested that the political rifts between the former mentor and protégé had truly melted away. Ma Ying-jeou and Wang Jin-pyng, key figures of the KMT, were also present, showing respect for the political godfather, even while the incumbent President came from the opposing party.

However, amid the glitz and political mingling, one former President was conspicuously absent: Lien Chan! Lien Chan's office cited "ill health" for his absence. Yet, at a milestone event like Lee Teng-hui’s 90th birthday, everyone present knew that his refusal to attend could not be explained away by a simple illness.

Let’s rewind to 2000. Lien Chan narrowly won the election, taking over from the Lee Teng-hui era. Although he opened the cross-strait "Mini-Three Links"—a significant policy—he was widely criticized for "political inertia" on domestic reforms. Political insiders reveal that Lien Chan’s conservative governance style failed to execute the native and structural reforms Lee Teng-hui had championed late in his career. This led to a complete breakdown in the relationship, transforming the former teacher-student bond into outright hostility.

The real drama unfolded during the 2004 Presidential Election. The Pan-Blue camp was fatefully split between Lien Chan and James Soong. Political gossip suggests that Lee Teng-hui, deeply dissatisfied with Lien, secretly mobilized his vast network of business friends and local political ties, channeling support toward Chen Shui-bian's campaign. Lee's alleged intention was to "teach a lesson" to the disobedient Lien Chan! Ultimately, the division of the Pan-Blue vote allowed Chen Shui-bian to narrowly stage a comeback, securing victory in 2004 and triggering the party rotation. Lien Chan, although receiving a higher vote share than Soong as the incumbent, squarely blamed his defeat on Lee Teng-hui's "betrayal." Consequently, James Soong was harshly criticized by the Pan-Blue base as the "sinner who split the camp," and has since borne that burden.

Today's banquet, featuring the reconciliation of Soong, Chen, and Lee, further confirms the complexity of that 2004 political triangle! Soong's presence suggests his political grievances with Lee have faded; Chen's appearance hints that the rumors of a "Lee-Chen alliance" were not baseless. Against this backdrop, Lien Chan clearly still harbors deep resentment over Lee Teng-hui's "underhanded strike" in 2004. His refusal to attend, more than a health issue, appears to be a silent, resentful protest against the century-defining political split and the invisible hand of Lee Teng-hui. This 90th birthday banquet has undoubtedly reopened one of the most twisted and dramatic chapters in Taiwan's political history!

TVBS Exclusive Report. The content of this news draft is compiled from political analysis and rumors, and does not represent the stance of this network.
`); // 2. Push the narrative (Tabloid/Apple Daily Style News Report - Full English, Focus on Social Class Conflict/Mockery, Updated Title and Comments) e.pages.push(`

★ BREAKING HEADLINE ★

Apple Daily Instant News | 2014/11/15

Facing Ko Wen-je, Young Master Lien's Campaign Fails to Connect! "It's Normal Not to Carry an EasyCard in a Suit Pocket" Quote Blows Up Online

The Lien family scion's "God Logic" ignites massive online mockery; voters question the KMT elite's understanding of common life.

The Taipei mayoral race is reaching a fever pitch! KMT candidate Lien Sheng-wen continues to struggle against non-partisan Ko Wen-je, who is heavily supported by the DPP. Although former President Lien Chan has frequently appeared on the campaign trail to save his son's candidacy, even bringing up his "Mini-Three Links" achievements, voters are clearly more focused on the vast disparity in the "Young Master Lien's" everyday life.

During a street sweep in Shilin Night Market yesterday, Lien Sheng-wen was captured by sharp-eyed media trying to buy a drink but unable to find any change. When a reporter pressed him on whether he regularly takes the MRT (Subway), Lien Sheng-wen smiled and replied, "Take the MRT? Of course I do! But isn't it normal not to carry an EasyCard (transit card) in my suit pocket? My bodyguards have them!"

This quote immediately exploded online! PTT netizens shared it wildly, mocking Lien Sheng-wen for exposing his "out of touch" elite lifestyle. Citizens questioned how a man who needs a bodyguard to carry his transit card could possibly understand the plight of Taipei residents who commute daily and struggle for a living.

Furthermore, former President Lien Chan's past achievements have become a focal point for the Ko Wen-je campaign. Ko's media team is aggressively attacking Lien Chan's eight-year presidency (2000-2008), claiming that while the "Mini-Three Links" may have dramatically increased the Lien family's wealth, they offered limited improvement to the "actual quality of life" for Taipei citizens. The Ko campaign is rallying voters with the slogan, "Break the monopoly of the privileged, bring back a common man mayor," which stands in sharp contrast to Lien Sheng-wen's "privileged quotes."

In response to the criticism, the Lien Sheng-wen campaign merely stated: "Mr. Lien is from a background of international finance elites, and his living habits may differ slightly from the average citizen, but his love for Taipei is the same. We urge Ko Wen-je to stop manipulating the election with class warfare!" However, voters are clearly unconvinced. In the latest polls, Lien Sheng-wen's support still lags Ko Wen-je by double digits, leaving the campaign in a precarious state.

Netizen Hot Discussion: Out-of-Touch Quotes (PTT Style)

[Push] Wuzui2000: Young Master Lien does take the MRT! He just takes his helicopter to look at the MRT!
[Push] TaiwanNo1: Lien probably thinks the EasyCard is a limited edition collaborative art piece, locked in his vault XD
[Boo] KMTout: Still dare to mention his dad's record? How much did our salaries actually increase in Lien Chan's eight years? What a joke!
